status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Patricia Valoy is a Latina feminist activist and blogger, and a Civil Engineer who promotes STEM education for women. She combines her experiences as a Latina, a feminist, and an engineer to advocate and inspire girls considering careers in the fields of STEM and speak on transnational feminism. Patricia's work mostly revolves around the Latino/a community, feminism, cultural identity, gender stereotypes, and workplace sexism.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Bias, Sexism, and Stereotypes in STEM
- STEM Outreach for Girls and Minority Groups
- Working in a Male-Dominated Fields
- Battling Sexism in STEM, Construction, and Other Non-Traditionally Female Employment
- Transnational Feminism and Cultural Identity
- Latina/o Feminism and Ethno-Racial Identity
link_name: Patricia Valoy - Everyday Feminism

It's Meet the Team Monday!

Hanna Brooks Olsen is a writer and policy wonk living in Seattle. Her career in writing has taken multiple turns and twists, but in the last few years, she's focused her energy on studying and reporting on issues of political economy, the labor movement, student debt, poverty, feminism, and where they all intersect. Her work has appeared in the Atlantic, Salon, the Nation, NPR, the Huffington Post, GOOD, Fast Company, Bitch, and many more wonderful places. You can follow her on Twitter at @mshanndbrooks (http://buff.ly/2nxztOJ). You can find her other thoughts on Medium: http://buff.ly/2nxpWqZ Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/2nxCaQB

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event!

Riley J. Dennis is non-binary trans woman, writer, YouTuber, activist, and educator. She worked as the Editor-in-Chief of the Quaker Campus newspaper, where she pushed Whittier College to reform how they dealt with cases of sexual assault. Through her YouTube channel, she works to educate the public on a range of issues all connected through social justice and intersectional feminism, mainly focusing on rape culture, gender identity, sexuality, and fatphobia.

Her presentations include:

- Fighting Rape Culture: How We Can Make Our Campuses Safer
- How Your College Newspaper Can Create Social Change
- Figuring Out Your Gender: How We Know Who We Are
- Fatphobia: Why Society Hates Fat People And How We Can Stop
- Intersectionality: How To Bring Others Into Your Feminism
link_name: Riley J. Dennis - Everyday Feminism

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Jessica Xiao is a self-proclaimed nerd and book hoarder who is guilty of tsundoku (http://buff.ly/2mbzSSw). Often inaccurately described as Canadian, she thinks of herself more as a Montrealer with US citizenship living in Washington, DC, after having obtained her BA & Sc. in Psychology and the dark art of Economics at McGill University. She is a grant writer for the Montreal-based international women's economic development nonprofit Artistri Sud (http://buff.ly/2mbkO7M) and the former assistant editor and writer at The Humanist (http://buff.ly/2mbfyAY). She believes in empathic action (http://buff.ly/2mbqX3v) and bringing our whole selves (http://buff.ly/2mbB4p6) to every aspect of our lives for transformational social change. She frequently quotes Dorothy Parker and writes bad poetry at stillsolvingforx.tumblr.com (http://buff.ly/2mbhn0G). You can also find her on Twitter @jexxicuh (http://buff.ly/2mJCdr4). Contact her especially if you have an eccentric side hustle you want to collab on or if you need a muse. Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2mJSmNk (FYI, the cotton candy is maple-flavored.)

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Kim Tran is a teacher, scholar and organizer finishing her PhD in Ethnic Studies and Gender, Women's and Sexuality Studies at the University of California, Berkeley. Her scholarship and community work engages the intersection of cross racial coalitions, gender inequality, class oppression and queer sexuality. Kim combines an academic and organizing background in queer literacy, intersectional feminism and anti-racist coalitions to inspire and deepen allyship and solidarity work.

Her presentations include:

- Uprooting Anti-Black Racism at Home
- Understanding the Queer Alphabet
- Anti-Oppression in the Classroom
- Navigating Internalized Racism
link_name: Kim Tran - Everyday Feminism

It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Ginny Brown is an EF contributing writer, sexuality educator, and birth worker. Her first decade of adulthood was spent making the journey from "homeschooled conservative Christian" to "queer polyamourous humanist." Now she's rocking it with an M.Ed in Human Sexuality from Widener University, and happily living in Philadelphia with her family of four adult humans and two cats. She is passionate about helping people know and love themselves better, and all of her work in sex education is secretly (or not-so-secretly) aimed at that goal. She's also working toward doula certification and super-excited to help people of all genders navigate pregnancy, birth, and new parenthood. She lazily co-writes a blog with her brother at The Brunette's Blog (http://buff.ly/2m9K3rG), and has been known to dabble in fiction writing as well. You can follow her on Twitter @lirelyn (http://buff.ly/2m9PgzE). Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2m9K4fe

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Michón Neal is a minority of minorities: female assigned at birth, mostly black, disabled, autistic, genderqueer, aromantic, pansexual, kinky, demisexual, poor, noetisexual, polyamorous, singleish, RA, a survivor, intersex, and left-handed. Michón Neal writes a mix of scifi, fantasy, erotica, and autobiography called cuil fiction about unique people in unique circumstances, with characters running the gamut of non-monogamous and LGBTQIA+ spectrums.

Hir presentations include:

- Intersectional Non-Monogamy
- How to Write Cuil
- The Forgotten Queers
- The Invisibility of Disability
- Aro Eros Arrows
- The Actual Sexual Spectrum
- Parental/Caregiver Privilege
- Ally In Action
link_name: Michón Neal - Everyday Feminism

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Alaina Leary is an intersectional feminist activist, editor, and publishing professional based in Boston, MA. She is currently a social media assistant for We Need Diverse Books, and is completing her MA in Publishing at Emerson College. Her career focus is on how to increase inclusive, authentic, intersectional representation in the publishing industry. She also edits for several online magazines, including Her Campus, Luna Luna Magazine, Germ Magazine, and Doll Hospital Journal. When she isn't busy reading, you can find her at the beach or curled up with her girlfriend and their two adopted literary cats. Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2lhcjXq

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Akilah Richards is a Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE) who specializes in women's emotional wellness.  Her work in centered on Radical Self-Expression, a practice she created to address societal oppression of the voices and needs of women and girls, and to explore the consequences and potential remedies therein. Akilah has created and delivered in-person and online workshops at college campuses, private summits, and public conferences about designing our ideal lives through the defining and exploration of self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle.

Her presentations include:

- Strategy & Soulwork for Radical Self-Expression
- Nurturing the Aha's: What to Do with Your Biggest Breakthroughs
- Life Design through Free-Range Learning: Exploring the Unschooling mindset
- Live Your Grain: Insights on Radical Lifestyle Management
- Life Chanting 101: How Incantations Support Spiritual Exploration
link_name: Akilah S. Richards - Everyday Feminism

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event!

B. Cole is the Founder and Executive Director of Brown Boi Project, a community of masculine of center womyn, men, two-spirit people, transmen, and allies committed to transforming privileges of masculinity, gender, and race into tools for achieving racial and gender justice. As a young queer consultant of color with almost ten years consulting and facilitation experience, she is often uniquely positioned to bring together groups across divides.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Justice
- The New Masculinity
- Resourcing a Movement

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Andrew Hernández is a Latinx public anthropologist, teacher, and writer. Hailing from the Midwest, he completed his PhD in Cultural Anthropology at the Graduate Center, City University of New York and now teaches at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. He is committed to making issues of social justice and liberation more accessible to public audiences. Andrew bases his research on human rights, crisis, and forced migration in West Africa. But he also writes about race, masculinity, Latinx identity, and privilege. You can follow him on Twitter @AndrewHernann (http://buff.ly/2lgY05z) or at his website (http://buff.ly/2lgOteF). Read his articles here: http://buff.ly/2lgZUTH

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

An award-winning public high school teacher in Seattle, Jon Greenberg gained broader recognition for standing up for racial dialogue in the classroom—with widespread support from community—while a school district attempted to stifle it. With nearly 20 years of diverse teaching experiences under his belt, he has long dedicated his teaching career to social justice and civic engagement.

His presentations include:

Teaching a Unit on Race: Practical Lessons on a Taboo Topic
The Race Curriculum Controversy: The Benefits and Costs of Social Justice Teaching
Civic Engagement 101: Connecting Your Classroom to the Community

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Adiba Nelson is one of our newest contributing writers! She spent much of her life feeling like "other," but that all changed when she went to a plus-size fashion show for Portland Fashion Week. That show proved to be the catalyst for some life changing transformations in her life, and since 2013, she has dedicated herself to living unapologetically. She is opinionated and snarky, and maybe a hair sarcastic (maybe), but she is also breathtakingly honest, saying the things you want to say but can't, won't, and maybe sometimes shouldn't. She is a former social worker who now spends her days baking cupcakes, holding strangers' babies, and helping ants completes their hills (sarcasm). She is *actually* a staunch advocate for body positivity/size acceptance, disability rights, and women being in charge of their own lives. You can find her ranting on Huffington Post, MyBrownBaby, Tucson Weekly, and on her own blog, The Full Nelson (http://buff.ly/2kKYYuK). You can also find her popping pasties as the stage scorching burlesque performer, The BIG Bang McGillicuddy (http://buff.ly/2kL2KUN).  If you'd like a less rant-y, G-rated version of Adiba, check out her children's book Meet ClaraBelle Blue (http://buff.ly/2kLaciy). 

Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2kL2Lbj

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Sandra Kim is the Founder and Executive Director of Everyday Feminism. Since its launch four years ago, Sandra has led Everyday Feminism to become one of the largest independent feminist media sites in the world, with 3-4 million visitors per month from over 150 countries. She also developed and leads the Compassionate Activism program and the Everyday Self-Love and Relationship online courses. Sandra's commitment to intersectionality and radical inclusiveness and her belief in the interdependence of personal and social transformation have shaped Everyday Feminism's unique approach to feminism.

Her presentations include:

- Compassionate Activism: Responding with Everyday Oppression with Love and Justice
- Applying an Intersectional, Inclusive Leadership Approach to Work and Organizations
- Bringing Intersectionality and Inclusiveness Into Our Daily Feminist Work
- Building an Intersectional and Inclusive Movement to End Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault
- Creating Authentic Anti-Oppression Cultures within Communities of Color
- Making Self-Care for Sustainable Activism the Norm
- Building a Massive Online Base for Social Change
link_name: Sandra Kim - Everyday Feminism

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Jennifer Loubriel is a mixed race Afro-Puerto Rican from the Bronx. She is also a queer mujerista and child abuse survivor. She earned her B.A. from Oberlin College in Religion and English, and identifies as an amateur Latinx ethicist and a speculative fiction enthusiast. She has previously worked as a community organizer and educator, where she taught and (un)learned with some deeply fabulous young women. She is a co-founder and moderator over at the Tumblr Women of Color, in Solidarity, a safe space for and by women of color (http://buff.ly/2jV6NwN). Jennifer is an aspiring radical librarian who thinks a lot about policing in community spaces. You can usually find her writing about apocalypse and diaspora, rewatching her favorite TV shows, or taking selfies with her family's cat. Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2jV0eKI

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event!

Adrian is a genderqueer writer, activist, consultant, and social justice educator as well as a state-certified mediator and trained facilitator. Adrian has founded/directed six youth programs focusing on topics ranging from food justice/farming/cooking to community organizing to youth ministry. They also consult with organizations on how to best improve diversity practices for staff and clients. They specialize in working with non-profits and schools/youth organizations on building best practices for trans, non-binary, and/0r gender non-conforming safety and inclusion.

Their presentations include:

- Non-Binary Identities 101
- How to Make Your Organization More Trans Inclusive
- Creating Trans-Affirming Youth Spaces
- Feminism and Trans Identities
- Youth Organizing and Adultism
link_name: Adrian Ballou - Everyday Feminism

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event!

Akilah Richards is a Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE) who specializes in women's emotional wellness.  Her work in centered on Radical Self-Expression, a practice she created to address societal oppression of the voices and needs of women and girls, and to explore the consequences and potential remedies therein. Akilah has created and delivered in-person and online workshops at college campuses, private summits, and public conferences about designing our ideal lives through the defining and exploration of self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle.

Her presentations include:

- Strategy & Soulwork for Radical Self-Expression
- Nurturing the Aha's: What to Do with Your Biggest Breakthroughs
- Life Design through Free-Range Learning: Exploring the Unschooling mindset
- Live Your Grain: Insights on Radical Lifestyle Management
- Life Chanting 101: How Incantations Support Spiritual Exploration
link_name: Akilah S. Richards - Everyday Feminism

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Carmen Rios splits her time disparately between feminist rabble-rousing, writing, public speaking, and flower-picking. A professional feminist by day and overemotional writer by night, Carmen is currently Communications Coordinator at the Feminist Majority Foundation and the Feminism and Community Editor at Autostraddle. In the past, she's blogged for the SPARK Movement and served as a Mic writer and Managing Editor of THE LINE Campaign blog.  Her successful work for over five years in digital feminism – ranging from Hollaback!'s successful launching Kickstarter campaign to the viral #EducateCoaches petition on Change – has earned her the titles of "digital native," "intimidating to some," and "vapid and uninteresting." Carmen is mother to the most adorable dog on Earth and hates paying more than one dollar for a good slice of pizza. You can follow her on Twitter @carmenriosss (http://buff.ly/2iCnKLV) and Tumblr (http://buff.ly/2iCl1Cj) to learn more about her feelings. Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2iClZOV

It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Alan Pelaez Lopez is an EF Contributing Writer and a quirky, gender non-conforming, Afro-Indigenous poet from Mexico City. Having been undocumented for sixteen years, Alan writes about the traumas of migration, growing up poor, and queer and trans activism. Besides Everyday Feminism, Alan makes and sells jewelry (http://buff.ly/2hbURFp), and is a graduate student at UC Berkeley (http://buff.ly/2hbXXt8) studying the cultural production of undocumented Black migrants. Read Alan's articles here: http://buff.ly/2hbTYwE

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Sam Dylan Finch is an LGBTQA+ and mental health educator. As a transgender person with mental illness, Sam draws from his lived experience to defy the stigmas that surround his identity, as well as teaching others about the challenges that are faced by his communities. With a passion for stigma-busting and impacting change through personal narratives and storytelling, Sam is quickly becoming a powerful and accessible voice for queer, feminist, and mental health issues.

His presentations include:

- What is Cis Privilege? An Essential Guide For Aspiring Allies
- Transgender 101 (For Those of Us Not On Tumblr)
- Mental Illness and Self-Love
- Transgender Mental Health: The Invisible Struggle
- A Movement for Everyone: Body Positivity For All Genders
link_name: Sam Dylan Finch

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Marina Watanabe is an Everyday Feminism Social Media Associate & Contributing Vlogger. She's a vlogger (http://buff.ly/2gSi9NX), blogger, overenthusiastic tweeter, and frustratingly close to being a college graduate (like, SO CLOSE). Marina identifies as mixed-race Japanese-American, a bisexual woman of color, a feminist, and a Gryffinclaw. She is particularly passionate about speaking of issues of sexual harassment and rape culture, overlapping intersectional identities, and fighting mental health stigma. She is currently majoring in Women's Studies and Communications at Sacramento State and hopes to continue using social media as a tool to discuss and raise awareness for feminist and social justice issues. Aside from creating video content for Everyday Feminism, she hosts a YouTube series called Feminist Fridays that explores the social, the political, and the media from a feminist and intersectional perspective – and uses a lot of F-words. She also runs a Tumblr called Everyday Harassment (http://buff.ly/2gSenUL) that serves as a safe space for women and members of marginalized groups to share their stories and educate others on the nature and frequency of sexual harassment. Check out her Tumblr (http://buff.ly/2gSgkAH), or follow her on Twitter @marinashutup (http://buff.ly/2gScGGY). Check out her videos here: http://buff.ly/2gSbR0C

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Patricia Valoy is a Latina feminist activist and blogger, and a Civil Engineer who promotes STEM education for women. She combines her experiences as a Latina, a feminist, and an engineer to advocate and inspire girls considering careers in the fields of STEM and speak on transnational feminism. Patricia's work mostly revolves around the Latino/a community, feminism, cultural identity, gender stereotypes, and workplace sexism.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Bias, Sexism, and Stereotypes in STEM
- STEM Outreach for Girls and Minority Groups
- Working in a Male-Dominated Fields
- Battling Sexism in STEM, Construction, and Other Non-Traditionally Female Employment
- Transnational Feminism and Cultural Identity
- Latina/o Feminism and Ethno-Racial Identity
link_name: Patricia Valoy

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Sandra Kim is the Founder and Executive Director of Everyday Feminism. Since its launch four years ago, Sandra has led Everyday Feminism to become one of the largest independent feminist media sites in the world, with 3-4 million visitors per month from over 150 countries. She also developed and leads the Compassionate Activism program and the Everyday Self-Love and Relationship online courses. Sandra's commitment to intersectionality and radical inclusiveness and her belief in the interdependence of personal and social transformation have shaped Everyday Feminism's unique approach to feminism.

Her presentations include:

- Compassionate Activism: Responding to Everyday Oppression with Love and Justice
- Applying an Intersectional, Inclusive Leadership Approach to Work and Organizations
- Bringing Intersectionality and Inclusiveness Into Our Daily Feminist Work
- Building an Intersectional and Inclusive Movement to End Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault
- Creating Authentic Anti-Oppression Cultures within Communities of Color
- Making Self-Care for Sustainable Activism the Norm
- Building a Massive Online Base for Social Change
link_name: Sandra Kim

status_message:
Last week's election of Donald Trump has sent a shock wave throughout the United States and across the world.  

In this difficult time, it's even more important that we learn how to heal the pain caused by systemic oppression. This frees us from the pain and fear that would lead us to respond with dehumanization and retribution. And instead we can lead with love and justice.

To support you in this work, we're sharing the video recordings of two past Compassionate Activism online workshops -- "Healing from Toxic Whiteness to Better Fight for Racial Justice" and "Healing from Marginalization through Love and Justice." 

These workshops offer a framework to understand how to get in touch with your pain in a gentle, affirming way and some immediate tools to help you move from a place of fear to a place of action.    

We invite you to check them out and hope they're able to provide you support through the times ahead with a sense of wholeness and shared humanity.
link_name: Compassionate Activism: Healing from Toxic Whiteness and Marginalization

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event!

Pidgeon Pagonis is an intersex artist, activist and former communications & operations manager and youth leadership coordinator for interACT youth—the world's first intersex youth project. Pidgeon has over ten years experience researching, advocating and educating a wide range of audiences about the intersex movement for bodily autonomy and justice. They've recently been published in the academic journal Narrative Inquiry in Bioethics, and were awarded by the White House as an LGBT Champion of Change. 

Their presentations include:

- Intersex is Beautiful: Binaries are Pitiful
- The Son I Never Had
- Something Else: Sex, Gender and Intersex
link_name: Pidgeon Pagonis

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Maisha Z. Johnson is the Digital Content Associate and Staff Writer of Everyday Feminism. She's a queer black writer and a creative facilitator who uses tools like blogging, social media, and unattended microphones to be super loud about her passion for social justice, even though she's an introvert. You can find her writing at the intersections and shamelessly indulging in her obsession with pop culture around the web. Maisha's past work includes Community United Against Violence (CUAV), the nation's oldest LGBTQ anti-violence organization, and Fired Up!, a program of California Coalition for Women Prisoners. Through her own project, Inkblot Arts, Maisha taps into the creative arts and digital media to amplify the voices of those often silenced. Find her passions and favorite animal photos on Tumblr (http://buff.ly/2f6IBBZ), like her on Facebook (http://buff.ly/2f6KTkL), or follow her on Twitter @mzjwords (http://buff.ly/2f6LMd2). Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2f6KRJF

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event!

Melissa A. Fabello is the Managing Editor of Everyday Feminism. She is also a body acceptance activist and sexuality scholar. Melissa is a licensed educator with over a decade of experience working with diverse populations, including extensive training in domestic violence and sexual assault prevention education. With a passion for advocacy and a drive for liberation, Melissa's work revolves mostly around body image, female sexuality, and media literacy.

Her presentations include:

- Why Feminism? Why Now?: An Introduction to the Movement and Why It Still Matters Today
- Media Literacy 101: How Pop Culture Seduces You into Gender Roles
- Bleeding Love: Pop Music, Advertising, and the Normalization of Dating Violence
- Reclaiming Our Bodies, Our Sexuality, Our Lives: Exploring Female Sexuality Through Five BS Body Myths
- Social Justice Activist Self-Care (or, Why My YouTube Comments Are Disabled): Why You Need It and How to Start
link_name: Melissa A. Fabello

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Josette Souza is the Program Director at Everyday Feminism. She's a working-class, Afro-latinx, first-generation college graduate hailing from semi-rural central Florida. After completing her B.A. in Africana Studies at Brown University in 2014, she worked for the Latinegr@s Project (http://buff.ly/2dRikX5) as a Digital and Social Media Intern, for Africa Educates (http://buff.ly/2dRgFAV) as the Social Media Coordinator, and taught English in Guanajuato, Mexico (where she soaked up the sun, at her weight in avocados, and made strides towards her goal of making friends with the Zapatistas (http://buff.ly/2dRkLIY)). Her favorite things in the world are Black liberation, intersectional feminism, and offering her condolences to the people who failed to bring her down by telling her that getting a degree in Africana Studies would mean never getting a good job. Read her articles and comics here: http://buff.ly/2dRepJN

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Kim Tran is a teacher, scholar and organizer finishing her PhD in Ethnic Studies and Gender, Women's and Sexuality Studies at the University of California, Berkeley. Her scholarship and community work engages the intersection of cross racial coalitions, gender inequality, class oppression and queer sexuality. Kim combines an academic and organizing background in queer literacy, intersectional feminism and anti-racist coalitions to inspire and deepen allyship and solidarity work.

Her presentations include:

- Uprooting Anti-Black Racism at Home
- Understanding the Queer Alphabet
- Anti-Oppression in the Classroom
- Navigating Internalized Racism

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your school or event! 

Sam Dylan Finch is an LGBTQA+ and mental health educator. As a transgender person with mental illness, Sam draws from his lived experience to defy the stigmas that surround his identity, as well as teaching others about the challenges that are faced by his communities. With a passion for stigma-busting and impacting change through personal narratives and storytelling, Sam is quickly becoming a powerful and accessible voice for queer, feminist, and mental health issues.

His presentations include:

- What is Cis Privilege? An Essential Guide For Aspiring Allies
- Transgender 101 (For Those of Us Not On Tumblr)
- Mental Illness and Self-Love
- Transgender Mental Health: The Invisible Struggle
- A Movement for Everyone: Body Positivity For All Genders
link_name: Sam Dylan Finch

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Vanessa Rochelle Lewis is a queer, lush-bodied, Black, femme performance artist, writer, actress, filmmaker, educator, facilitator, orator and Faerie Queen Mermaid Gangsta for The Revolution. She is the Senior Editor for Everyday Feminism; co-host of the queer/feminist Open Mic, Culture Fuck; and Director of queer, Black, multi-disciplinary performance troupe, Congregation of Liberation. She just went on tour with Sister Spit 2016. She uses a combination of memoir, poetry, theatre, and feminist storytelling to advance her politix of radical love, socioeconomic justice, anti-racism, community accountability, critical reflection, love, healing, and liberation. Check out her website at buff.ly/2enN1oK (http://buff.ly/2dvftG8). Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2enNYgM

Cole is the Founder and Executive Director of Brown Boi Project, a community of masculine of center womyn, men, two-spirit people, transmen, and allies committed to transforming privileges of masculinity, gender, and race into tools for achieving racial and gender justice. As a young queer consultant of color with almost ten years consulting and facilitation experience, she is often uniquely positioned to bring together groups across divides.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Justice

- Resourcing a Movement

Bring an Everyday Feminism Speaker to your event! 

Patricia Valoy is a Latina feminist activist and blogger, and a Civil Engineer who promotes STEM education for women. She combines her experiences as a Latina, a feminist, and an engineer to advocate and inspire girls considering careers in the fields of STEM and speak on transnational feminism. Patricia's work mostly revolves around the Latino/a community, feminism, cultural identity, gender stereotypes, and workplace sexism.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Bias, Sexism, and Stereotypes in STEM
- STEM Outreach for Girls and Minority Groups
- Working in a Male-Dominated Fields
- Battling Sexism in STEM, Construction, and Other Non-Traditionally Female Employment
- Transnational Feminism and Cultural Identity
- Latina/o Feminism and Ethno-Racial Identity
link_name: Patricia Valoy

status_message:
Book an Everyday Feminism speaker for your event!

Sandra Kim is the Founder and Executive Director of Everyday Feminism. Since its launch three years ago, Sandra has led Everyday Feminism to become one of the largest independent feminist media sites in the world, with 3-4 million visitors per month from over 150 countries. She also developed and leads the Compassionate Activism program and the Everyday Self-Love and Relationship online courses. Sandra's commitment to intersectionality and radical inclusiveness and her belief in the interdependence of personal and social transformation have shaped Everyday Feminism's unique approach to feminism.

Her presentations include:

- Compassionate Activism: Responding with Everyday Oppression with Love and Justice
- Applying an Intersectional, Inclusive Leadership Approach to Work and Organizations
- Bringing Intersectionality and Inclusiveness Into Our Daily Feminist Work
- Building an Intersectional and Inclusive Movement to End Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault
- Creating Authentic Anti-Oppression Cultures within Communities of Color
- Making Self-Care for Sustainable Activism the Norm
- Building a Massive Online Base for Social Change
link_name: Sandra Kim

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Melissa A. Fabello is the Managing Editor of Everyday Feminism. She is also a body acceptance activist, sexuality scholar, and patriarchy smasher living in Philadelphia. She is a doctoral candidate at Widener University, working toward a PhD in Human Sexuality Studies, where her research focus is on women with anorexia nervosa and the bodied phenomenon of skin hunger. She also holds an M.Ed. in Human Sexuality from Widener, as well as a B.S. in English Education from Boston University. Melissa has also done extensive work for The National Eating Disorders Association (http://buff.ly/2dswIX3), The Representation Project (http://buff.ly/2dswLCg), Adios Barbie (http://buff.ly/2dsyoQn), and Laci Green's Sex+ community (http://buff.ly/2dsxzal). She enjoys rainy days, tattoos, and cats, and probably knows more about Jurassic Park than feminism. You can find her in all corners of the Internet (Facebook (http://buff.ly/2dswY8A), Twitter (http://buff.ly/2cZ1fjw), Tumblr (http://buff.ly/2dl4GN1), Instagram (http://buff.ly/2dl4a1v), and YouTube (http://buff.ly/2dl4ayx). Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2d2mpe8 And book her for speaking engagements here: http://buff.ly/2dsxMuh

status_message:
Book an Everyday Feminism speaker for your event!

Pidgeon Pagonis is an intersex artist, activist and former communications & operations manager and youth leadership coordinator for interACT youth—the world's first intersex youth project. Pidgeon has over ten years experience researching, advocating and educating a wide range of audiences about the intersex movement for bodily autonomy and justice. They've recently been published in the academic journal Narrative Inquiry in Bioethics, and were awarded by the White House as an LGBT Champion of Change.

Their presentations include:

- Intersex is Beautiful: Binaries are Pitiful
- The Son I Never Had
- Something Else: Sex, Gender and Intersex
link_name: Pidgeon Pagonis

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism Speaker to Your Event!

Riley J. Dennis is a non-binary trans woman, writer, YouTuber, activist, and educator. She worked as the Editor-in-Chief of the Quaker Campus newspaper, where she pushed Whittier College to reform how they dealt with cases of sexual assault. Through her YouTube channel, she works to educate the public on a range of issues all connected through social justice and intersectional feminism, mainly focusing on rape culture, gender identity, sexuality, and fatphobia.

Her presentations include:

- Fighting Rape Culture: How We Can Make Our Campuses Safer
- How Your College Newspaper Can Create Social Change
- Figuring Out Your Gender: How We Know Who We Are
- Fatphobia: Why Society Hates Fat People And How We Can Stop
- Intersectionality: How To Bring Others Into Your Feminism
link_name: Riley J. Dennis

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Kim is a teacher, scholar and organizer finishing her PhD in Ethnic Studies and Gender, Women's and Sexuality Studies at the University of California, Berkeley. Her scholarship and community work engages the intersection of cross racial coalitions, gender inequality, class oppression and queer sexuality. Kim combines an academic and organizing background in queer literacy, intersectional feminism and anti-racist coalitions to inspire and deepen allyship and solidarity work.

Her presentations include:

- Uprooting Anti-Black Racism at Home
- Understanding the Queer Alphabet
- Anti-Oppression in the Classroom
- Navigating Internalized Racism

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Adrian Ballou is a genderqueer writer, activist, consultant, and social justice educator as well as a state-certified mediator and trained facilitator. Adrian has founded/directed six youth programs focusing on topics ranging from food justice/farming/cooking to community organizing to youth ministry. They also consult with organizations on how to best improve diversity practices for staff and clients. They specialize in working with non-profits and schools/youth organizations on building best practices for trans, non-binary, and/0r gender non-conforming safety and inclusion.

Their presentations include:

- Non-Binary Identities 101
- How to Make Your Organization More Trans Inclusive
- Creating Trans-Affirming Youth Spaces
- Feminism and Trans Identities
- Youth Organizing and Adultism

It's Win of the Week Wednesday! 

This week, the Everyday Feminism staff is excited about: Indigenous activists' protests to halt construction of a new oil pipeline in North Dakota

Why we're excited: Check out this video about Native activists' historic actions to shut down construction of a new oil pipeline! As the protest gains strength, officials have ordered police to cut off protesters' water supply, but the protesters are still standing strong in the sweltering heat. 

Spread the word and let's build support for this important action! 
-Maisha Z. Johnson, Staff Writer and Digital Content Associate

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Akilah Richards is a Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE) who specializes in women's emotional wellness.  Her work in centered on Radical Self-Expression, a practice she created to address societal oppression of the voices and needs of women and girls, and to explore the consequences and potential remedies therein. Akilah has created and delivered in-person and online workshops at college campuses, private summits, and public conferences about designing our ideal lives through the defining and exploration of self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle.

Her presentations include:

- Strategy & Soulwork for Radical Self-Expression
- Nurturing the Aha's: What to Do with Your Biggest Breakthroughs
- Life Design through Free-Range Learning: Exploring the Unschooling mindset
- Live Your Grain: Insights on Radical Lifestyle Management
- Life Chanting 101: How Incantations Support Spiritual Exploration
link_name: Akilah S. Richards

status_message:
Our thoughts are with everyone in Baton Rouge and Southern Louisiana who have been affected by the recent flooding. People are becoming more aware of what's happening, but we haven't seen nearly as much media coverage as there should be - and this poignant explanation by Donney Rose shows why: 

"What needs to be understood is that there is a segment of our population that went from being met with aggression by a militarized police force last month to losing a great bit of what they own in this month's flooding. There are for real people who have been doubly victimized by governmental negligence, by state sanctioned violence and by infrastructural neglect based on zip code.

This is what the phrase "most vulnerable" means. It is when classism makes you most susceptible to harm by man-made authority and/or natural harm that you don't get a barrier from. And by barrier I mean it is lazy to suggest that victims of breaking levies or poor drainage systems, are victims of God's will being done. Nah, they are by and large victims of the same disregard of life as victims of police violence, dictated by the same disproportionate use of tax dollars.

Which all has much less to do with divine dismissal of "everything happening for a reason" and more to do with exact reasons that everything seems to always happen to a specific populace."

Here's information on how you can support the victims: http://buff.ly/2biylHa
link_name: Ted James - As many of you know, parts of #BatonRouge and... | Facebook

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Marina Watanabe is a vlogger (http://buff.ly/2aUGQFb), blogger, overenthusiastic tweeter, and frustratingly close to being a college graduate (like, SO CLOSE.) Marina identifies as mixed-race Japanese-American, a bisexual woman of color, a feminist, and a Gryffinclaw. She is particularly passionate about speaking of issues of sexual harassment and rape culture, overlapping intersectional identities, and fighting mental health stigma. She is currently majoring in Women's Studies and Communications at Sacramento State and hopes to continue using social media as a tool to discuss and raise awareness for feminist and social justice issues. Aside from creating video content for Everyday Feminism, she hosts a YouTube series called Feminist Fridays that explores the social, the political, and the media from a feminist and intersectional perspective – and uses a lot of F-words. She also runs a Tumblr called Everyday Harassment (http://buff.ly/2aUGgYc) that serves as a safe space for women and members of marginalized groups to share their stories and educate others on the nature and frequency of sexual harassment. Check out her Tumblr (http://buff.ly/2aUGb6A), or follow her on Twitter @marinashutup (http://buff.ly/2aUGE93). Check out her videos here: http://buff.ly/2aUHcM2

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Ellen Kate is a health educator, sometime writer, and mom. After doing a BA in Women's Studies in her hometown of Vancouver, Ellen moved to New York where she did a Master's degree in Health and Human Sexuality Education. Since then, she has worked at Manhattan's Museum of Sex, developed sex education curricula in Mumbai, India, and run HIV prevention programs for at-risk teens in the South Bronx. Currently, Ellen teaches human sexuality at Brooklyn College (something she also did at Rutgers University). Currently, she is the coordinator of a middle and high school health education program at a school in Brooklyn.  For years, Ellen also ran About .com's LGBT Teens site (http://buff.ly/2aGEnEe). Before that, she wrote for Planned Parenthood's teen website and blogged about sex education for gURL (http://buff.ly/2aGF3tx). More of Ellen's writing can be found here: http://buff.ly/2aGEsYv. In addition to work-related projects, Ellen spends a lot of time with her three kids, tries to find time to run, and dreams of learning another language. Follow her on Twitter @ellenkatef (http://buff.ly/2aGEnUK). Read her EF articles: http://buff.ly/2aGF3K3

status_message:
Hello, wonderful community! We get hundreds of messages each week from you asking us for advice and personalized assistance in applying intersectional feminism to your lives. And since we're such a small team, it's really hard for us to reply to them.

But we really want to! So that's inspired us to think of ways to serve this need in a way that's sustainable for us. 

We'd like to know if you'd be interested in an interactive online membership program to help share advice and resources, take your intersectional feminism to another level, and build community for a small membership fee.

But we'll only offer this if a lot of you want to enroll in it! 

So please like this FB post if you want us to create it. And give us feedback on what would make it truly valuable and useful to you!

For example, do you have specific goals or challenges in your life that you'd like our advice and support? Possible topics could be how to incorporate more social justice practices into your work or personal life or develop a career in social justice.

Perks to the online membership program could include Q&A sessions with staff, social justice seminars and workshops, group discussions, and more.

What other topics or perks would you like this program to offer? We'd love to hear from you!
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Carmen Rios splits her time disparately between feminist rabble-rousing, writing, public speaking, and flower-picking. A professional feminist by day and overemotional writer by night, Carmen is currently Communications Coordinator at the Feminist Majority Foundation and the Feminism and Community Editor at Autostraddle. In the past, she's blogged for the SPARK Movement and served as a Mic writer and Managing Editor of THE LINE Campaign blog.  Her successful work for over five years in digital feminism – ranging from Hollaback!'s successful launching Kickstarter campaign to the viral #EducateCoaches petition on Change – has earned her the titles of "digital native," "intimidating to some," and "vapid and uninteresting." Carmen is mother to the most adorable dog on Earth and hates paying more than one dollar for a good slice of pizza. You can follow her on Twitter @carmenriosss (http://buff.ly/2aqfMRe) and Tumblr (http://buff.ly/2aqfOIX) to learn more about her feelings. Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/2aqfZny

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week, the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: The internet's hilarious response to Melania Trump's plagiarism of Michelle Obama's speech

Why we love it: Oh, the RNC. I wouldn't exactly call the beginning of the Republican National Convention a "win," but as for the internet's response to the discovery that Donald Trump's wife Melania repeated passages from First Lady Michelle Obama's 2008 speech? GOLDEN. 

Some people say focusing on this is a distraction from more pressing issues – like the overt racism and xenophobia that Republican leaders have expressed over the past few days. And it's true that it's important to keep the bigger picture in perspective. 

But personally, I appreciated the moment of levity that came with having some fun with this moment. And this has also brought some attention to an issue that's not trivial at all – the fact that Black women so often find our words and our work repeated by and credited to other people more accepted by mainstream society. 

It's no laughing matter. But in the spirit of the long tradition of laughing to keep from crying, many have spun this moment into comedy gold with some hilarious memes and hashtags like #FamousMelaniaTrumpQuotes. Here are some of the funniest ones people came up with. Enjoy! 
-Maisha Z. Johnson, Staff Writer and Digital Content Associate
link_name: Melania Trump Speech Memes Are The Best Thing To Come Out Of The Republican Convention

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Sam Dylan Finch is queer writer, activist, and educator, based in the San Francisco Bay Area. A passionate feminist and social justice advocate, Sam explores topics such as transgender identity, mental health and illness, radical self-love, and queer feminism. Sam is particularly interested in impacting social change through personal narrative and memoir. As a transgender, mentally ill queer, Sam draws from his lived experience with the hopes of educating others about his communities, and challenging the stigmas that surround his identity. In addition to being the Editorial Coordinator and a Staff Writer at Everyday Feminism, he is the founder of Let's Queer Things Up! (http://buff.ly/2anPBZU). When he isn't writing, he's probably belting out a Mary Lambert song in the shower, or thinking up new ways to (lovingly) annoy his partner. You can find him on Twitter @samdylanfinch (http://buff.ly/2anPUnz), Facebook (http://buff.ly/2anQoK4), Instagram (http://buff.ly/2anPsp7), or learn more about him at his personal website (http://buff.ly/2anPgGq). Read his articles here: http://buff.ly/29Q1c2P

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday! 

This week, the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: Jesse Williams and Shonda Land!

WHY WE LOVE IT: If you missed actor Jesse Williams' speech at the BET Awards, please check it out now – this is a message that needs to be spread far and wide. 

I could hardly control my excitement over this incredible truth-telling on national TV. If you follow me on Twitter or Tumblr, I ain't sorry for blowing up your feed with quotes and gifs and more during this moment – it had to be done. 

While accepting a Humanitarian Award, Jesse brought us face-to-face with some uncomfortable – but deeply important – truths about racism, violence, and everyday people's roles in it.

Typically, there's now backlash against him. A growing petition is calling for Jesse to be fired from his role on Grey's Anatomy – but the people signing it don't know who they're dealing with. In a single tweet, showrunner Shonda Rhimes shut down all that noise, saying, "Um, people? Boo don't need a petition. #shondalandrules".

And I just LOVE this moment of passionately pursuing justice in the face of opposition – AND the fact that we've got a Black woman who's fought her way to such an influential position in the media, that she can laugh the haters off and do what's right. It doesn't always seem possible to break these barriers. But Shonda's done it, Jesse's right there with her, and I'm inspired by the doors they're opening for more and more people to unapologetically proclaim that BLACK. LIVES. MATTER. 
-Maisha Z. Johnson, Staff Writer and Digital Content Associate  

P.S. I wrote this before I heard of the Baton Rouge police shooting death of Alton Sterling – and I'd just like to honor him in this post, holding his family, friends, and community in my heart, and say we won't stop fighting for him and all the other victims we never should've lost to police violence.
link_name: Refinery29 - Grey's Anatomy fans want Jesse Williams fired... | Facebook

Hari Ziyad is Black genderqueer artist and writer whose work centers on creating through the arts alternative ways of living outside of systems of oppression. Their work is informed by their passion for storytelling and wrestling with identity as a Black, genderqueer child of Muslim and Hindu parents. Hari deals primarily with identity, race, gender and sexuality, ally politics and the arts.

- The Role of Arts In Creating Futures Free of Oppression
- The Limitations of Ally Politics

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week, the Everyday Feminism staff is excited about: The Supreme Court ruling that upholds tribal jurisdiction to support Native survivors!

Why we love it: Do you know about the crisis of violence against Native women and children? 4 in 5 Native Americans have been raped, stalked, or abused in their lifetime, and 1 in 3 Native women has been raped, stalked, or abused in the past year alone – almost all by someone who is not Native.

So in the recent Supreme Court case Dollar General vs Mississippi Band of Choctaws, a ruling against the tribe would have meant that no American Indian Nation would be able to try any civil case involving a Non-Native person or corporation – the most damaging decision to the rights of Native people in over half a century. 

Instead, the Supreme Court tied in a 4-4 decision – so the lower court ruling in favor of the tribe stands!

Read a moving statement on this case from Force: Upsetting Rape Culture and The Monument Quilt, along with an infographic that shows just how much was at stake, here: http://buff.ly/294qmwu

And check out this article that FORCE co-founder and co-director Rebecca Nagle wrote on how the US legal system leaves Native survivors vulnerable – and how you can listen to Native advocates working on this issue and do something to help.
link_name: The US Supreme Court Is About To Consider the Most Potentially Devastating Case For Native Nations

status_message:
Why We Stopped Doing Image Descriptions in Our Facebook Posts (and how people with visual impairments are still able to get the image description):

[Edit: This announcement has been updated in order to clarify confusion.]

Hello, EF community! We'd like to share with you an announcement regarding our image descriptions. 

Over the last few weeks we've worked on moving the location of the image descriptions from our Facebook posts to inside the articles themselves, underneath the feature image as well as in the alt text. 

With this change, all people who rely on image descriptions will have access to them, regardless of whether they come from our FB page or from one of the many other avenues people use to get our content. This decision was made based on all the feedback we've gotten relating to image descriptions and how people who use them found them most accessible and useful. 

You can find more information about this and our other ongoing efforts to make this an accessible, inclusive page by reading our comments policy here: http://buff.ly/28W7xse

Please let us know if you have any questions or concerns. We wouldn't be able to do what we do without your ongoing support and feedback, so thank you!
link_name: Our Facebook Comments Policy

It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Anis Gisele is a queer immigrant writer, by way of Manila, Philippines. Her work is celebrated as much as it is minimized and/or blindly consumed. She is a 2016 Everyday Feminism fellow, a 2016 VONA/Voices fellow (fiction), and a 2016 King Country Artist for Equity and Social Justice (poetry). Outside of her resume, she is a lifelong Tara Hardy student, an Ocean Vuong devotee, and a very part-time dancer with aggressive shoulders. She is grateful for this fellowship that allows her to write, publish, and remain in her integrity.

status_message:
It's the season for LGBTQIA+ Pride – and some people in our communities think having more police at Pride events will keep us safe. 

But is more policing really the answer? Yesterday, news broke that another one of the officers involved in the Baltimore death of Freddie Gray was acquitted of all charges. 

This is yet another example of the criminal justice system treating people of color like we're disposable – and LGBTQIA+ people of color are particularly vulnerable. 

So, do you still think more police will make a safer Pride? Here's a reality check on just how damaging the alliance between white LGBTQIA+ folks and law enforcement really is.


[Image: A police car with sirens flashing on a dark street.]
link_name: Why the Growing Alliance Between Police and White LGBTQIA+ Folks Is a Problem

An award-winning public high school teacher in Seattle, Jon Greenberg gained broader recognition for standing up for racial dialogue in the classroom—with widespread support from community—while a school district attempted to stifle it. With nearly 20 years of diverse teaching experiences under his belt, he has long dedicated his teaching career to social justice and civic engagement.

His presentations include:

- The Race Curriculum Controversy: The Benefits and Costs of Social Justice Teaching

status_message:
This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: The Queer Body Love Speaker Series, hosted by Elizabeth Cooper, Queer Body Love Coaching

Why we love it: The Queer Body Love Speaker Series is a free month-long online event for queer and trans folks to feel free and confident in their bodies and their lives. And this is so important because the intersection of queer/trans identity and body image is so rarely explored in mainstream conversation. With 30 awesome experts (including Sonya Renee Taylor from The Body Is Not an Apology, Dan Maldonado and Jaden Fields from T-Ffed: Trans Folx Fighting Eating Disorders , and our very own Co-Managing Editor, Melissa A. Fabello), you're bound to learn something new. So if you're interested in learning more about feeling peaceful around food, having amazing sex, navigating the healthcare system, and more, you can sign up to receive the video series here: http://thequeerbodyloveseries.com/mfabello

[Image: A poster reads "Queer Body Love speaker series," with photos of Melissa A. Fabello and Elizabeth Cooper, and the website http://buff.ly/28Jv1B6 at the bottom]

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Michón Neal is a minority of minorities: female assigned at birth, mostly black, disabled, genderqueer, aromantic, pansexual, kinky, demisexual, poor, noetisexual, polyamorous, singleish, RA, a survivor, intersex, and left-handed. Michón Neal writes a mix of scifi, fantasy, erotica, and autobiography called cuil fiction about unique people in unique circumstances, with characters running the gamut of non-monogamous and LGBTQIA+ spectrums.

Hir presentations include:

- Intersectional Non-Monogamy
- How to Write Cuil
- The Forgotten Queers
- The Invisibility of Disability
- Aro Eros Arrows
- The Actual Sexual Spectrum

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday! 

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is honoring: QTPOC spirit, resistance, and resilience after the tragedy in Orlando

Why we love it: This week, it feels hard to celebrate a "win." The attack on Latin night at a Pulse, an Orlando LGBTQ nightclub, has all of my attention, and I am crushed. 

I'm a queer Black woman, and dancing with other LGBTQIA+ people of color is hands down one of my favorite things to do in the entire world. This was an attack on a sacred space, and the way I'm feeling now is a lot like how I felt in the immediate aftermath of the shooting at a Black Charleston church. Numb. Terrified. Devastated. 

And it's only thanks to LGBTQIA+ POC community that I don't feel defeated. We're making it possible for each other to heal, to do what feels nearly impossible in continuing to live our lives after such unspeakable tragedy. 

I've seen art and poetry, odes to the sanctity of "Latinx night at the gay club," a time for celebration and joy and love we can only find by resisting white supremacy and heteropatriarchy, reconnecting with indigenous and spiritual and embodied wisdom that we carry in our bodies and spirits.

I've read the words of unimaginably resilient queer and trans Muslims refusing to be silent or invisible or forgotten. There have been vigils, healing circles, and loving check-ins between LGBTQIA+ people of color who recognize one another's pain. 

Yes, we're also speaking with allies, discussing policy changes, and calling out politicians and other leaders responsible for our social norms and institutions that other and criminalize LGBTQIA+ people of color, immigrants, and Muslims. These actions have an important place in the movement.

But truth be told, we can only get through this because we have each other. We don't need fake allies, and we're not begging for validation from people who dehumanize us every day. 

We're creating our own space in the world by standing together, prioritizing our own healing, and honoring the inherent, undeniable value of the people we've lost and those of us who are still here. 

As the proudly Black bisexual poet June Jordan once wrote, "We are the ones we have been waiting for." Thank you, LGBTQIA+ people of color, for being here with me. -Maisha Z. Johnson, Staff Writer & Digital Content Associate


[Image: Two people embrace side by side, consoling each other in front of a crowd holding candles and rainbow flags at a vigil for the victims of the Pulse nightclub shooting.]
link_name: American Ugliness: Queer and Trans People of Color Say ''Not in Our Names''

It's Meet the Team Monday!

Sherina Ong is a Filipina American writer, journalist, and intersectional feminist who believes that stories speak louder than words. She loves to explore the concepts of race/ethnicity, gender, pop culture, and all the messiness in between. Outside of being a Writing Fellow for Everyday Feminism, Sherina juggles freelance writing, radio producing and trying to get people to care about minorities through NextDayBetter (http://buff.ly/1UJfgwS), a storytelling platform for Filipino and Asian Pacific Islander diaspora communities. And if she's not doing any of those things, she's probably either watching Parks and Rec for the 1500th time or serenading her two pet bunnies with her ukulele. You can follow her on Medium (http://buff.ly/1UJdZWF) and Twitter @sherinaong (http://buff.ly/1UJf3tw). Find her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1UJeDn4

status_message:
We are so heartbroken after the mass shooting in Orlando, FL. Our thoughts are with our LGBTQIA+ communities there, across the US and all around the world.

It's all the more heartbreaking for this to happen during Pride month – a time when we celebrate our communities and remember that, in a world with so much hatred for who we are, it is a fiercely political act of resilience to find our joy.

We remember that in moments like this, the most vulnerable people are those living at the intersections of multiple marginalized identities. This attack happened in an LGBTQ nightclub, on a Latinx night. So the impact is especially difficult for Latinx folks in LGBTQIA+ communities.

There are also LGBTQIA+ Muslim people who are hurting right now. After an attack by someone who calls themselves a Muslim, or is even suspected to be a Muslim, incidents of Islamophobic violence, discrimination, and criminalization rise against innocent Muslim people.

In the midst of this terrible attack, we're also reeling from the routine criminalization of LGBTQIA+ people of color, deportations and abusive detentions of LGBTQIA+ immigrants, horrific violence targeting trans women of color, anti-trans legislation in places like North Carolina, and more.

So, though we still have much to celebrate this Pride month, we remember that we still have a lot to fight for. Systems including homophobia, transphobia, patriarchy, white supremacy, and more are taking our lives, as the video below highlights.

Let's look out for each other, love ourselves, and honor the lives we never should have lost to these hideous acts of violence.
link_name: Familia: Trans Queer Liberation Movement

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week, the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: "Can We Talk About Whiteness?," the first episode of the new Code Switch podcast from NPR.

Why we love it: This new podcast by NPR is a shiny new glimmer of hope in the big, white sea that is public radio/the podcast world. Hosted by journalists of color, the first episode of Code Switch asks you "Ever find yourself in a conversation about race and identity where you just get...stuck?" Countless numbers of you all have told us that you do indeed struggle with conversations on race (particularly when it comes to whiteness), whether it be about navigating privilege, dealing with your racist relatives, or explaining to your partner why that comment was hurtful. We hope that you're able to give this podcast a listen and check out some of its interesting and enlightening content. - Josette Souza, Program Coordinator


[Image: The words "code switch" in letters swaying in different directions.]
link_name: Code Switch

Richards is a six-time author, digital content writer, and lifestyle coach who writes passionately about self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle. status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday! 

This week, the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: The Supreme Court granting a new trial for Timothy Foster

Why we love it: A black man named Timothy Foster was sentenced to death in 1987 - in a ridiculously blatant example of racial discrimination. We know a single case couldn't possibly erase the whole tragic impact of racism in the criminal justice system, but we all need to be paying attention to moments like this - and urging those in power to follow this lead. 

Can you imagine waiting 30 years in prison for a moment like this? We can't undo the injustices of the past, but we can insist on taking a new path. -Sandra Kim, Founder & Executive Director

Check out this compelling testimony by Bryan Stevenson on abolishing the death penalty: https://everydayfeminism.com/2016/04/death-penalty-testimony/


[Image: A photo focusing on Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. applauding at the 2016 State of the Union address with several others standing behind him.]
link_name: The Supreme Court just sent a strong message about racism in the justice system

status_message:
Maisha Z. Johnson is the Digital Content Associate and Staff Writer of Everyday Feminism. She's a queer black writer and a creative facilitator who uses tools like blogging, social media, and unattended microphones to be super loud about her passion for social justice, even though she's an introvert. You can find her writing at the intersections and shamelessly indulging in her obsession with pop culture around the web. Maisha's past work includes Community United Against Violence (CUAV), the nation's oldest LGBTQ anti-violence organization, and Fired Up!, a program of California Coalition for Women Prisoners. Through her own project, Inkblot Arts, Maisha taps into the creative arts and digital media to amplify the voices of those often silenced. Find her passions and favorite animal photos on Tumblr (http://buff.ly/1XXxTQE), like her on Facebook (http://buff.ly/1XXy2Ug), or follow her on Twitter @mzjwords (http://buff.ly/1XXxFsB) Read her articles here: http://buff.ly/1XXxWvJ

News just broke that Amber Heard filed a restraining order against actor Johnny Depp, alleging in divorce proceedings that he was abusive – and already comments doubting her story are rolling in. 

The survivors in your life are listening to these conversations. So here's a reminder that even if you think someone is a talented actor, attractive, or a "good" person, they can still be capable of abuse.

We have to stop believing the myth that only "monsters" can be abusive, and start standing with survivors.

Have you ever found yourself wishing that activism didn't have to be so draining, retraumatizing, and unsustainable? 

We have, and that's why we've created the Compassionate Activism training program to arm activists with the tools they need to heal from systemic oppression and build their capacity to respond to everyday oppression with both love and justice. 

Check out more information on this virtual training (including the scholarships!) here: http://www.compassionateactivism.com/program/virtual-training/.

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday! 

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: these nine plus-size androgynous babes

Why we love it: This week's win is brought to you by these nine plus-size androgynous babes.

Androgyny is typically presented as white, thin, and conventionally attractive – these gorgeous humans defy these ideals and they do it with killer style. 

Androgyny, contrary to mainstream belief, is for any and all bodies. Fat bodies, black and brown bodies, disabled bodies, queer bodies. Androgyny is more than Ruby Rose; androgyny is more than Tilda Swinton. Androgyny is as varied as the people who embrace it.

As a genderqueer and chunky cutie myself, I am SO here for diverse representations of androgyny. They help us to dream of what's possible for ourselves, and help us to feel validated and whole in our bodies.

While this list certainly doesn't cover the full spectrum of androgynous people, it's a great place to start. I hope you find as much joy in it as I did. -Sam Dylan Finch, Editorial Associate & Feature Writer 


[Image: Three photos show Ree Melanen, Heather Rae Martin, and Marquis Neal posing for the camera.]
link_name: 9 Plus Size Cuties Share Tips For Androgynous Style

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Josette Souza is the Program Coordinator at Everyday Feminism. She's a working-class, Afro-latinx, first-generation college graduate hailing from semi-rural central Florida. After completing her B.A. in Africana Studies at Brown University in 2014, she worked for the Latinegr@s Project (http://buff.ly/1NFsVWr) as a Digital and Social Media Intern, for Africa Educates (http://buff.ly/1NFsStL) as the Social Media Coordinator, and taught English in Guanajuato, Mexico (where she soaked up the sun, ate her weight in avocados, and made strides towards her goal of making friends with the Zapatistas (http://buff.ly/1NFsVpb)). Her favorite things in the world are Black liberation, intersectional feminism, and offering her condolences to the people who failed to bring her down by telling her that getting a degree in Africana Studies would mean never getting a good job. Find her on Twitter @josette_souza (http://buff.ly/1NFsStw) and read her articles and comics here: http://buff.ly/1NFsVFT.

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday! 

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: Co-Editor Jezebel Delilah X's fundraiser for her upcoming theatrical production, Congregation of Liberation Presents: Black Rage//Black Magic (http://buff.ly/23WBEVT)

Why we love it: The production of Black Rage//Black Magic is the result of a 16 week theatrical healing workshop that I, Jezebel Delilah X, co-facilitated with my creative partner, Tha HoodAlkemist, for Black people in the Bay Area FOR FREE. The workshop created a safe space for participants to use playwriting, theatre games, ritual, and conversation to move through their rage, pain, heartbreak, and trauma as a result of constantly experiencing anti-black racism (and other intersectional oppressions) in their personal lives, and witnessing it so horrifically in unending display of police/systemic violence broadcasted in our communities and on the media. 

Within the workshop, participants and facilitators created a series of short plays and performance art pieces centered around their Black Rage and the magical ways we heal and move through it. The production will be June 1st and 2nd at SAFEhouse Arts in San Francisco (http://buff.ly/23WBOwv).

As a bullied kid, it was theatre that saved my life, that helped me move from being angry at, and afraid of, the world into a fierce determination to create change, to fight for social justice and healing, and to knowing that I am just as valuable and important as every one else. It was theatre that kept me alive, that helped me love myself, and that helped me learn to love others. While contemporary racism consistently works to set people of color back, while blaming us from our struggles, theatre is a phenomenal way to fight back, to speak up, and to remind each other of our collective beauty, our powerful self-efficacy, and the glory of our resilience. Theatre is a magical wand that can nurture self esteem, healing, and community in the face of any bully - including racism.

I could really use any and all help in this venture - we want to pay our participants and produce more free workshops in community. Please check out our fundraising video, and if you feel moved please support our campaign by donating to it and sharing it with your friends (http://buff.ly/23WBEVT). 

Thank you for EVERYTHING!!!!! -Jezebel Delilah X, Co-Managing Editor
link_name: Black Rage // Black Magic - Oakland

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Neve Be, a Contributing Writer for Everyday Feminism and the great great grandchild of the author of the Velveteen Rabbit, grew up a little wild along rivers, still loves to swim and dance, and is working on becoming real with the world they love. Neve has written for Harlot Magazine, Curve Magazine, Plenitude Magazine, and Model View Culture. Their erotic performance persona Lyric Seal is the voice behind the advice column Slumber Party, and an essay of theirs was published in the anthology "Coming Out Like a Porn Star" edited by Jiz Lee. As a multigender, mixed black, disabled, queer femme party and performance diva anarchist with PTSD, Neve likes to write and speak about trauma, healing, ethics, equity and critical theory, entertainment culture, relationships, our relationships to our bodies, and art and love at large, all through the lens of disability justice. You can visit and catch Neve as they fall into the deep and star speckled internet on Instagram (@littlebeasthood), Twitter (@littlebeasthood), and Tumblr (http://buff.ly/1TaOhNq). Some people will find these sites not safe for work. You can book Neve or Lyric to speak or dance for your group or community, they'd love to!

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event! 

Patricia Valoy is a Latina feminist activist and blogger, and a Civil Engineer who promotes STEM education for women. She combines her experiences as a Latina, a feminist, and an engineer to advocate and inspire girls considering careers in the fields of STEM and speak on transnational feminism. Patricia's work mostly revolves around the Latino/a community, feminism, cultural identity, gender stereotypes, and workplace sexism.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Bias, Sexism, and Stereotypes in STEM
- STEM Outreach for Girls and Minority Groups
- Working in a Male-Dominated Fields
- Battling Sexism in STEM, Construction, and Other Non-Traditionally Female Employment
- Transnational Feminism and Cultural Identity
- Latina/o Feminism and Ethno-Racial Identity


[Image: A photo of featured speaker Patricia Valoy sitting and talking on a red sofa on a stage while holding a mic with her hand.]
link_name: Patricia Valoy

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week the Everyday Feminism Staff is excited by: Mental Health Awareness Month

Why we love it: May is Mental Health Awareness Month! There are always plenty of reasons to talk about mental health, but having a whole month dedicated to it gives me hope that we can create the space to support each other in our struggles.

I deal with anxiety, depression, and trauma from sexual and intimate partner violence – a beast of a combination. It's a real struggle, and sometimes I feel so ashamed, like I'm just a failure and the only one who's feeling this way.

So I'm immensely grateful for people who speak out about their mental health struggles and let me know that I'm not alone. This year, I've been especially thankful for people discussing mental health from an intersectional perspective, recognizing that we all have unique challenges.

Because, while mental illness affects people of all backgrounds, we don't all have the same experience. Men, for example, have the burden of being told it's not okay to express their emotions. People of color often struggle to find service providers who understand the stigma in our communities. Queer, trans, and gender non-conforming can face medical professionals who demonize their identities.

So here's one of my favorite celebrations of Mental Health Awareness Month: MayBeWell's collection of 2-minute videos on mental health in the Black community. There is far too much silence about mental health in my community, but with one video being released for each day of May, I'll have lots of voices to remind me that I'm not alone. -Maisha Z. Johnson, Staff Writer and Digital Content Associate

You can read more about why intersectionality matters in mental health and on the intersections with race from Matthew Rodriguez here: http://mic.com/articles/142387/here-s-why-we-need-mental-health-action-not-mental-health-awareness#.nUINYBmzx


[Image: A black banner reads "MayBeWell" in blue and white letters.]
link_name: THE COLLECTION

status_message:
It's Meet the team Monday!

Breeshia is a playwright, poet and essayist who identifies as a queer, sex positive, survivor who loves all things sacred and profane. She received her BA in Comparative Studies in Race and Ethnicity, focus in Creative Writing from Stanford University, and is currently pursuing a dual Master's in Divinity and Social Work at the University of Chicago. She is actively cultivating her practice as an intersectional feminist, philosopher and theologian, exploring the intersections of art, BDSM and spirituality. She is more interested in being a guide opposed to a leader, and she hopes to find ways to combine performance art and creative writing to allow people to engage their own spiritual possession. Although she was raised Southern Baptist, her current spiritual practices include a mixture Buddhism and Christianity. Her research and activism focuses on violence prevention/intervention, identity construction, healing and personal narrative.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Taté Walker is a Lakota feminist activist, blogger, filmmaker, photographer, and social services professional who promotes cultural competency and inclusion for professionals in the workplace. Her experience includes more than 10 years as a newspaper reporter and freelance journalist, juvenile justice worker, teacher, and civil rights and family advocate. This, combined with her personal, professional and academic research in the areas of Native American identity and stereotypes, poverty, health, and sexuality, make Taté a dynamic and powerful speaker.

Her presentations include:

- Gender & Sexuality in Native American Cultures
- The Role of Women in Native American Societies from 1492 to Today
- Surviving Love: Promoting Awareness & Prevention of Violence Against Indigenous Women
- 566: An Introduction to Native American Cultural Competency
- Not Your Tonto: Native American Representations in Media
- The Harm of Indian Mascots on Native American Youth
- Not Your Cliché: A Look at the Stereotypes Plaguing Tribal Communities
- Columbus, the Discovery Myth, and the Importance of Teaching Indigenous Histories
- Moving Past the Thanksgiving Fairytale
- Topics specific to the Oceti Sakowin (Seven Council Fires, often mistakenly referred to as "Sioux")


[Image: A portrait of featured speaker Taté Walker looking forward, smiling, and sitting with one arm resting on a ledge.]
link_name: Taté Walker

It's Win of the Week Wednesday!  

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by:  The Abundant Bodies track at the Allied Media Conference

Why we love it: I've always been jealous of folks who attend the yearly Allied Media Conference in Detroit because it always looks chockfull of amazing activism. But when I found out that there's an Abundant Bodies track, I thought maybe it was about time to look into attending. According to the conference website, this track "explore[s] how we can use media and art to transform mainstream ideas around abundant bodies, challenge fatphobia, and create resilient communities," centering on the experiences of "indigenous, Black, People of Color, Dis/abled, Supersized, Trans and Queer fat folks." But they need your help fund their presenters and events! So if you're interested in supporting this kick-ass and necessary conference track, please consider donating. - Melissa A. Fabello, Co-Managing Editor
link_name: Abundant Bodies: Fat Lovin Media Futures 2016

Melissa A. Fabello is a Co-Managing Editor of Everyday Feminism. She is a licensed educator with over a decade of experience working with diverse populations, including extensive training in domestic violence and sexual assault prevention education. With a passion for advocacy and a drive for liberation, Melissa's work revolves mostly around body image, female sexuality, and media literacy.

Her presentations include:

- Why Feminism? Why Now?: An Introduction to the Movement and Why It Still Matters Today
- Media Literacy 101: How Pop Culture Seduces You into Gender Roles
- Bleeding Love: Pop Music, Advertising, and the Normalization of Dating Violence
- Reclaiming Our Bodies, Our Sexuality, Our Lives: Exploring Female Sexuality Through Five BS Body Myths
- Social Justice Activist Self-Care (or, Why My YouTube Comments Are Disabled): Why You Need It and How to Start

It's Meet the team Monday!

Pidgeon Pagonis is an intersex Chicagoan who believes binaries are better smashed. They, why yes they do prefer gender neutral pronouns, recently received a LGBT Champions of Change Artist award from the White House—and no, the White House didn't include the I. They engage in local organizing against police, school closures and the prison industrial complex because they believe the intersex struggle for bodily autonomy and justice is intimately intertwined with Black liberation. Parent to the world's cutest Rottweiler named Callie, Pidgeon earned a Bachelor and Masters of Women & Gender Studies at DePaul University. Recent hobbies include learning about physics, quantum mechanics and pondering the ever expanding universe (aka watching The Cosmos on Netflix). Follow Pidgeon on Twitter @pidgejen (http://buff.ly/1NJ9lTt), peep their etsy (http://buff.ly/1NJ9oyx…), book them to speak (http://buff.ly/1NJ9lTw), or keep up with them on FB (http://buff.ly/1NJ9lTE).
