status_message:
Only four more days to apply for our new Fellowship Program! :) Applications are due on Monday April 25th. 

The Fellowship is a 6-month training and mentorship program for activists who write at the intersection of personal and social liberation. Fellows will learn the very writing approach that has helped Everyday Feminism reach 3-4 million people per month in less than 4 years and made more radical politics accessible, appealing, and relevant to a more mainstream audience.

This is a virtual program and Fellows can be anywhere in the world as long as they have Internet access and can participate in the online workshops, which will be held during US business hours. The hours are also flexible with only the online workshops being at a specific time.

For more info and to apply, check out: http://everydayfeminism.com/get-involved/fellowship-program/


[Image: A person with medium-length brown hair smiling, standing outside, and holding a laptop on their raised knee.]
link_name: Fellowship Program

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sandra Kim is the Founder and Executive Director of Everyday Feminism. Since its launch three years ago, Sandra has led Everyday Feminism to become one of the largest independent feminist media sites in the world, with 3-4 million visitors per month from over 150 countries. She also developed and leads the Compassionate Activism program and the Everyday Self-Love and Relationship online courses. Sandra's commitment to intersectionality and radical inclusiveness and her belief in the interdependence of personal and social transformation have shaped Everyday Feminism's unique approach to feminism.

Her presentations include:

- Applying an Intersectional, Inclusive Leadership Approach to Work and Organizations
- Bringing Intersectionality and Inclusiveness Into Our Daily Feminist Work
- Building an Intersectional and Inclusive Movement to End Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault
- Creating Authentic Anti-Oppression Cultures within Communities of Color
- Making Self-Care for Sustainable Activism the Norm
- Building a Massive Online Base for Social Change

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday! 

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: #UnfairAndLovely

Why we love it: The Unfair and Lovely campaign is simply GORGEOUS – dark-skinned South Asian women telling colorism to GTFO of their lives and self-image by celebrating their dark skin tones. 

I'm a Black woman with dark skin, so I know colorism well – the pressure to lighten your skin, the back-handed compliment that says you're "pretty for a dark girl." So I LOVE that this campaign started when a Black woman, Pax Jones, took photos of sisters Mirusha and Yanusha Yogarajah, who are of Sri Lankan descent. They decided to post the pictures with the hashtag #UnfairAndLovely – and encourage dark-skinned women of all backgrounds to reject the global colorism phenomenon by sharing their own selfies and celebrations of dark skin. 

Along with hashtagslike #ReclaimtheBindi, which pushes back against cultural appropriation of South Asian symbols, and other anti-colorism campaigns like #FlexinMyComplexion and #IwillNotApologizeforBeingDarkSkin, this social media movement shows how we can use digital tools and our own images to reject the systems trying to keep us down. 

Sending all my love and solidarity to South Asian women and all of us who are unfair and lovely – no matter what the media or anyone else says.
 – Maisha Z. Johnson, Staff Writer and Digital Content Associate 

Visit Pax Jones' website at: http://buff.ly/1rkSO3T


[Image: A photo from the Unfair and Lovely Instagram page show two South Asian women, one leaning on the other, both staring at the camera with serious expressions.]
link_name: Women of colour around the world are taking part in the #UnfairandLovely campaign

status_message:
Everyday Feminism happy to announce we are now offering a Fellowship Program!

The Fellowship is a 6-month training and mentorship program for activists who write at the intersection of personal and social liberation. Fellows will learn the very writing approach that has helped Everyday Feminism reach 3-4 million people per month in less than 4 years and made more radical politics accessible, appealing, and relevant to a more mainstream audience.

This is a virtual program and Fellows can be anywhere in the world as long as they have Internet access, can write on intersectional topics in English, and can participate in the webinars, which will be held during US business hours.

To learn more about this Fellowship and to apply, check out: http://everydayfeminism.com/get-involved/fellowship-program/


[Image: A person with medium-length brown hair standing outside, smiling, and holding a laptop on a raised knee.]
link_name: Fellowship Program

status_message:
It's Meet the team Monday!

Jezebel Delilah X is a queer, lush-bodied, Black, femme performance artist, writer, actress, filmmaker, educator, facilitator, orator and Faerie Queen Mermaid Gangsta for The Revolution. She is a Co-Managing Editor for Everyday Feminism; co-host of the queer/feminist Open Mic, Culture Fuck; and Director of queer, Black, multi-disciplinary performance troupe, Congregation of Liberation. She just went on tour with Sister Spit 2016. She uses a combination of memoir, poetry, theatre, and feminist storytelling to advance her politix of radical love, socioeconomic justice, anti-racism, community accountability, critical reflection, love, healing, and liberation. Check out her website at www.jezebeldelilahx.com

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!  

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: National Poetry Month

Why we love it: April is National Poetry Month, and poetry is one of my first loves. It's one of my main sources of healing, tools for creating social change, and resources for reminding myself that my voice matters. And I really love having a whole month to celebrate poetry because it's a chance to lift up some of my heroes who have changed the world – Audre Lorde, Alice Walker, June Jordan, just to name a few faves. These powerful poets and more are featured on For Harriet's list of "11 Poetry Collections by Black Writers Everyone Should Read." Check them out and share your favorite poets in the comments! – Maisha Z. Johnson, Staff Writer and Digital Content Associate 


[Image: Overlapping book covers show parts of Sonia Sanchez, Maya Angelou, Audre Lorde, Alice Walker, and Nikki Giovanni's poetry collections.]
link_name: 11 Poetry Collections by Black Writers Everyone Should Read

Miri Mogilevsky is a Contributing Writer for Everyday Feminism and a counselor living in Columbus, Ohio. She has a BA in psychology from Northwestern University and a Masters in Social Work from Columbia University. Her blog, Brute Reason (http://buff.ly/232qd0p), covers topics like psychology, mental health, social justice, sexuality, and more. Miri adores cats, cities, and Cheez-Its of all shapes and sizes. status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: an open, honest look at fatphobia and disordered eating with a subtle feminist message in Mona Awad's "13 Ways of Looking at a Fat Girl."

Why we love it: Most literary books that cover intersections of fatphobia, disordered eating, and diet culture tend to either do so in a way that's harmful and triggering or awkwardly over-the-top in its feminist delivery, leaving us unfulfilled. But Mona Awad's new book, "13 Ways of Looking at a Fat Girl" manages to have these conversations in an honest, raw, and nuanced way – without falling into the common traps of the genre. These thirteen stories come together to illustrate the ups and downs in the life of Lizzie, exploring the various ways that fat, food, and fitness shape our lives. According to The Washington Post, by the time the subtle, brilliant message is spelled out at the end of the novel, "You'll want to grab a friend and say: 'Whoa. This. Exactly.'" And I couldn't agree more. - Melissa A. Fabello, Co-Managing Editor


[Image: A photo of the cover of the featured book, "13 Ways of Looking at a Fat Girl" by Mona Awad.]
link_name: 13 Ways of Looking at a Fat Girl: Fiction: Mona Awad: 9780143128489: Amazon.com: Books

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Kai Cheng Thom is a writer, performance artist, social worker, and glitter enthusiast based in Montreal, Canada. In addition to Everyday Feminism, her articles have been published in xoJane, Youngist, and Montreal Review of Books. Her poetry has appeared in Matrix Magazine, Ditch, Yellow Noise Magazine, and the anthology Where the Nights are Twice as Long: Love Letters of Canadian Poets. A little Chinese trans girl with a big, lipsticked mouth, she has rocked spoken word stages from Vancouver to Halifax. Kai also holds a Master's degree in social work and is training to become a psychotherapist. She is the co-founder of Monster Academy Montreal, a youth mental health education collective. In her spare time, Kai is learning to pick locks and make dresses. You can check out her website (http://buff.ly/25su6Ov), follow her poetry Tumblr(http://buff.ly/1PAMetC), or follow her on Facebook! Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1PAMhWw. 

[Image: A headshot of featured team member Kai Cheng Thom standing on stage, looking up, and holding a microphone.]

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: the incredible leadership and activism of the Black youth who kicked Anita Alvarez out of office in Chicago.

Why we love it: Following former Chicago prosecutor Anita Alvarez's decision not to charge former police officer Jason Van Dyke with the murder of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald until a year after the murder and only when the video of the murder that she and other officials worked to bury came to light, Black youth activists and those in solidarity with them have finally succeeded in ousting Alvarez from office. 

As BBC reporter Jessica Lussenhop writes, "The Black Lives Matter movement has been criticised for its lack of focus, aversion to a hierarchical structure, and inability to translate rage from street protests into tangible political goals... But [March 16th's] results answered those criticisms with definitive proof of the movement's real political clout."

This victory shows us all that the future of our world lies squarely and powerfully in the hands of our young people of color, hands that have and will continue to usher in justice in the face overwhelming odds. - Sandra Kim, Founder and Executive Director 


[Image: A photo showing three people standing in a group of protestors, the person in the middle looking forward with a solemn expression and the two behind them looking to their right.]
link_name: Chicago prosecutor loses her fight with Black Lives Matter - BBC News

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: 

The recent news that one of the biggest and most heinous players in the global prison industrial complex, G4S, will be selling their Israeli subsidiary, and getting out of the U.S. and U.K. youth prison businesses within the next two years.   

Why we love it: 

After years of campaigning for justice, the global #BDS (Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions) movement has finally succeeded in pushing the British private "security" company G4S out of Israel, a company that's served as a key agent in Israel's abuse and torture of its 7,000 Palestinian prisoners (many of them children as young as 11 years old). 

This victory extends beyond Palestine, as the announcement made by G4S included the news that they will be exiting out of US "youth justice services" and UK "children's services" -- detention centers known for their abuse of children, particularly children of color. 

As Jewish Voice for Peace Executive Director Rebecca Vilkomerson put it, "This win shows the power of building coalitions in solidarity with one another based on a common principle - challenging mass incarceration and racist policing whether it is happening in the US, UK, or Israel." 

And as Adv. Sahar Francis, Director of Addameer Prisoner Support and Human Rights Association noted: "The latest reports that G4S will sell its subsidiaries in Israel is welcome news but this has no immediate effect on those facing human rights violations inside Israel's prisons today."

There is still much work to be done, and we look forward to the continued success of all movements for peace and justice. 

- Josette Souza, Program Coordinator


[Image: A photo of a protester holding a sign that has the name "G4S" stricken out and the words "Proudly Servicing Israeli Apartheid" written around it.]
link_name: Landmark boycott victory as G4S says it is leaving Israel

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: The Live Through This Project  (Content warning: suicide) 

Why we love it: As a suicide attempt survivor, I have found myself feeling completely alone as I navigate life after my attempt. That's why I want to share this project, which is a collection of portraits, accompanied by stories, of suicide attempt survivors.

The project, founded by the amazing Dese'Rae L. Stage, has filled me with so much affirmation in a society which often erases and invisibilizes the experiences of survivors. The portraits are not only beautiful, but the stories that go along with them are touching, at times heartbreaking, and shed a light on a community that is seldom acknowledged.

Dese'Rae, thank you for the incredible work that you do. I knew that I wasn't alone in my experiences – but your project is proof that we can and we do live through this.

- Sam Dylan Finch, Editorial Associate & Staff Writer


[Image: An illustration of two colorful birds holding a banner that reads "Live Through This."]
link_name: Live Through This

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Patricia Valoy is a Contributing Writer for Everyday Feminism, as well as an engineer and project manager, feminist writer, and STEM advocate. She writes and speaks on a variety of issues pertaining to women in STEM and other male-dominated fields, particularly as it relates to women of color and underrepresented minorities. Patricia's advocacy is on attracting and retaining women in STEM careers and building work environments where women are free from discrimination, sexism, and racism. She also speaks and writes on a variety of issues affecting the Latinx community including racism, immigration, cultural and religious pressures, and living at the intersection of two cultures. She is the STEM chairperson for the Women's Information Network in New York, and the best dog mom in the world to her two pups. Her feminist rants can be found in her blog Womanisms (http://buff.ly/1LBmVMZ), and on Twitter @PatriciaValoy. Read her Everyday Feminism articles here: http://buff.ly/1LBmORq and contact her via Facebook here: http://buff.ly/21WfHap.

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week the Everyday Feminism Staff is excited by Queer, Black Organizer Ashley Williams. 

Why we love them: On February 24th, 2016, Ashley attended a $500 plate dinner fundraiser for Hillary Clinton, reminded the world that she has publicly called Black youth "Super Predators," and asked her to apologize to Black people for Mass Incarceration. As Hillary's supporters booed, insulted, hissed, and escorted Ashley out of the building, Hillary dismissed their presence and concerns by saying, "ok, back to the issues...." As if promoting and instigating the blatantly racist mass incarceration of predominately poor and working class Black people - a political movement that continues to rip apart families, lives, and communities -- is not an issue for a major presidential candidate.

Well, Ashley, despite those boos, hisses, and insults you had to endure, I want you to know that I am so proud of you and so grateful for your courage. Your activism and organizing is clearly rooted in a bravery fortified by self and community love. You, and your work, embody what hope and a belief in the possibility of change can look like. I would have loved to witness Hillary take this wonderful opportunity you offered her to show us that she can and will be accountable to racial justice, that change is possible, and that she honors the voices of the people. This would have been the perfect time for her to demonstrate that people can grow, learn, and heal from the socializations of white supremacy, that political candidates can be honest, self-reflective, and accountable allies for their more marginalized constituents - and not money hungry politicians exploiting the racialized pain, trauma, and oppression of people of color for more power and a political platform. 

You, Ashley, are a hero and I am honored by your existence. If Hilary does become our next president, I wish her the courage, the grace, and the love for community and justice that you displayed at her fundraising dinner. Thank you for your commitment to liberation. 

- Jezebel Delilah X, Co-Managing Editor


[Image: A photo of activist Ashley Williams holding a sign at a fundraising event for Hillary Clinton that reads "We have to bring them to heel."]
link_name: We Spoke to Ashley Williams, the Black Queer Organizer Who Interrupted Hillary Clinton

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sandra Kim is the Founder and Publisher of Everyday Feminism. Since its launch three years ago, Sandra has led Everyday Feminism to become one of the largest independent feminist media sites in the world, with 4.5 million visitors per month from over 150 countries. Sandra's commitment to intersectionality and radical inclusiveness and her belief in the interdependence of personal and social transformation have shaped Everyday Feminism's unique approach to feminism.

Her presentations include:

- Applying an Intersectional, Inclusive Leadership Approach to Work and Organizations
- Bringing Intersectionality and Inclusiveness Into Our Daily Feminist Work
- Building an Intersectional and Inclusive Movement to End Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault
- Creating Authentic Anti-Oppression Cultures within Communities of Color
- Making Self-Care for Sustainable Activism the Norm
- Building a Massive Online Base for Social Change


[Image: A headshot of featured speaker Sandra Kim sitting on a couch, crossing her arms, and smiling.]
link_name: Sandra Kim

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: #1000BlackGirlBooks by Marley Dias

Why we love it: 11-year-old activist Marley Dias has touched my whole heart and soul by launching #1000BlackGirlBooks – a drive to collect 1,000 books with black girl protagonists. As a black girl book nerd, I had to laugh when Marley explained that she's tired of always reading about "white boys and dogs." Even as a dog lover, I remember that exact frustration from my childhood. 

And I'm apparently not alone in being moved – Marley reached her goal! She's collected over 1,000 books and the donations are still pouring in. She plans to send them to US and Jamaican schools, helping more children find vital affirmation in stories that reflect their lives. I'm sure this isn't the last we'll hear from Marley Dias – so be on the lookout for this inspiring leader in #BlackGirlMagic! 

- Maisha Z. Johnson, Digital Content Associate & Staff Writer


[Image: A photo of young activist Marley Dias standing in front of a colorful board and holding four books she's collected as part of her book drive.]
link_name: Marley Dias's Book Drive For Black Girls Is Officially A Huge Success - The Frisky

status_message:
Meet the Team Monday!

Kel Kray is a Contributing Writer for Everyday Feminism. They are a fiercely friendly social justice warrior who spends their days advocating with and on behalf of queer youth at an LGBTQIA+ youth center in Philly. A firm believer in the transformative power of dialogue, Kel coordinates a youth-driven education and training program that facilitates community workshops on gender and sexuality with an intersectional lens. A righteous product of the Midbest, Kel earned a Bachelor of Women's Studies at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and a Master of Social Work at the University of Pennsylvania. When not shaking a fist, Kel can be found wearing printed leggings, eating a hearty casserole, and doing a crossword while their snugglebuddy Tum Tum Geraldine naps on their lap. Follow Tum Tum on Instagram @peeping_tum. Read their EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1mM2aCA. 

[Image: A close up of featured writer Kel Kray laughing and looking away from the camera.]

Adrian is a genderqueer writer, activist, consultant, and social justice educator as well as a state-certified mediator and trained facilitator. Adrian has founded/directed six youth programs focusing on topics ranging from food justice/farming/cooking to community organizing to youth ministry. They also consult with organizations on how to best improve diversity practices for staff and clients. They specialize in working with non-profits and schools/youth organizations on building best practices for trans, non-binary, and/0r gender non-conforming safety and inclusion.

Their presentations include:

- Non-Binary Identities 101
- How to Make Your Organization More Trans Inclusive
- Creating Trans-Affirming Youth Spaces
- Feminism and Trans Identities
- Youth Organizing and Adultism

status_message:
It's Win of the Week Wednesday!  

This week the Everyday Feminism staff is excited by: "Juliet Takes a Breath" by Gabby Rivera. 

Why we love it: 

Inga Muscio's review of this Gabby Rivera novel is 'Even if Holden Caulfield was born in the Bronx in the 1980s, he could never be this awesome' – and as a big fan of "Catcher in the Rye," I wasn't so sure it would live up to this hype. But this book was a hugely pleasant surprise, and I couldn't put it down. Following the story of a baby-queer Latina navigating feminism (and encountering situations that help explain concepts like white feminism and polyamory to the reader), Rivera creates palpable struggles through vivid characters and gorgeous prose. Even Roxane Gay tweeted about how brilliant this book is. And if that's not a good enough reason to pick up a copy, then let me add my promise to you: You won't regret it. - Melissa Fabello, Co-Managing Editor


[Image: The front cover of the book showing an illustration of a person facing away from the camera, with the words "Juliet Takes a Breath" shaved into the back of their head.]
link_name: Juliet Takes a Breath: Gabby Rivera: 9781626012516: Amazon.com: Books

Sian Ferguson is a Contributing Writer at Everyday Feminism and a queer, polyamorous, South African feminist who is currently studying towards a Bachelor of Arts majoring in English and Anthropology. She studies at the institution currently known as Rhodes University in Grahamstown, where she works as the chairperson of the Gender Action Project (http://buff.ly/1LjMn4a). Her work has been featured on websites such as Women24, Foxy Box and Matador Network while also writing for her personal blog (http://buff.ly/1o7YcFP). Follow her on Twitter @sianfergs.

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Akilah Richards is a Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE) who specializes in women's emotional wellness.  Her work in centered on Radical Self-Expression, a practice she created to address societal oppression of the voices and needs of women and girls, and to explore the consequences and potential remedies therein. Akilah has created and delivered in-person and online workshops at college campuses, private summits, and public conferences about designing our ideal lives through the defining and exploration of self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle.

Her presentations include:

- Strategy & Soulwork for Radical Self-Expression
- Nurturing the Aha's: What to Do with Your Biggest Breakthroughs
- Life Design through Free-Range Learning: Exploring the Unschooling mindset
- Live Your Grain: Insights on Radical Lifestyle Management
- Life Chanting 101: How Incantations Support Spiritual Exploration


[Image: A headshot of featured speaker Akilah Richards standing in front of a body of water and looking directly at the camera.]
link_name: Akilah S. Richards

It's Meet the Team Monday!

Akilah S. Richards is a Contributing Writing for Everyday Feminism. She is a six-time author, digital content writer, and lifestyle coach who writes passionately about self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle. She is a storyteller who believes in the power of expressed personal narrative and deep self-acceptance as tools for authentic self-expression and community enrichment. Her works have been featured in national magazines such as Essence, Real Simple, and Rolling Out, and on several digital media sites including Rolling Out, Tiny Buddha, and Atlanta Blackstar, among others. Connect with Akilah on Instagram (http://buff.ly/1nJQKQw), Tumblr (http://buff.ly/1SLEQkO), or her #radicalselfie e-home, radicalselfie.com. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1nJQS2w.

Creigh Farinas is a neurodiversity activist and blogger, and an advocate for autism acceptance. Despite studying autism as part of her coursework, her extensive knowledge about autistic and disabled people's perspectives comes from her personal background as a sibling of an Autistic woman and former caregiver for children on the autism spectrum. She uses her experiences and observations to inform her as she attempts to amplify the voices of autistic people. Creigh's background mostly revolves around disability rights, neurodiversity, and autism acceptance.

Her presentations include:

- Autistic People Can Lead Happy Lives: Helping Them Get There
- Why Would Anyone Want to Accept Autism? An Explanation of the Autism Acceptance Movement 
- Presuming Competence: What That Means for You
- The Social Model of Disability: How Someone Can Be Simultaneously Very and Not at All Disabled
- How to Be an Ally to Neurodiverse People
- Teaching Kids about Disabilities
- What is Autism?


[Image: A headshot of featured speaker Creigh Farinas smiling widely and facing the camera directly.]
link_name: Creigh Farinas

status_message:
Did you hear about yesterday's Black Lives Matter protests? Activists from Black Seed, a black queer liberation collective, shut down the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge to call for an end to police violence. 

This action was part of #96Hours to #ReclaimMLK – reminding us that the true spirit of Martin Luther King Jr Day includes the honoring power of civil disobedience to fight injustice. The protesters came with a set of demands to address the San Francisco police killing of Mario Woods.

But not everyone is getting the message. Some people say that these protests are too "disruptive," and they don't see how blocking traffic helps the cause. 

So if you're objecting to this action, this article has what you need to know about why using civil disobedience to address police brutality makes perfect sense – and why you're standing in the way of justice if you're trying to dismiss the need to declare that #BlackLivesMatter.

For powerful photos of the Black Seed protest and more information about their message that #BlackHealthMatters, you've got to check out the breathtaking images by Brooke Anderson Photography: Stills of Our Stories & Struggles here: http://on.fb.me/1PDrwtH
link_name: Here's What You're Missing When You Object to the Black Lives Matter Protests

Michón Neal is our newest Social Media Associate & Contributing Writer!

Ze writes a mix of scifi, fantasy, erotica, and autobiography called cuil fiction about unique people in unique circumstances, with characters running the gamut of non-monogamous and LGBTQIA+ spectrums. That's right: queer and poly fiction! Ze is currently working on the Cuil Effect project (http://buff.ly/1n3TAjC), a ridiculously long tale about healing, absurdity, and all the different ways people interact. You can find more details, sneak peeks, links, and absurdity on hir blog, Shadow in the Mirror (http://buff.ly/1nml3gd). Ze also invented the only class on Intersectional Non-Monogamy (http://buff.ly/1TYPymR) and is the co-editor for Postmodern Woman (http://buff.ly/1Q1rqif). status_message:
Many feminists organizations (us included) have been getting a lot of comments demanding that we condemn the horrible sexual violence that recently took place in Cologne, Germany.

These attacks were horrendous violations of women's bodies and the survivors absolutely deserve support. But we've also noticed a trend amongst those calling for justice in this particular instance - that many of them are people who ordinarily dismiss rape culture, such as conservatives and anti-feminists like Fox News. 

And while we agree wholeheartedly that justice needs to happen, something's very off about this call for justice – namely, that it's rooted in xenophobia and Islamophobia. The right wing is using this specific incident of sexual violence to whip up support for anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim policies as if only Muslim men commit sexual violence. 

So let's be clear, sexism is embedded in every culture. We need to work year round to dismantle rape culture and end sexual assault regardless of who is targeted and who perpetrates them - including and especially within each of our own communities. 

Because as this author writes, "You know what has never yet prevented sexual violence? Unbridled racism."


[Image: A group of protesters in Cologne, Germany holding a banner that reads "Mädelbund Henriette Reker."]
link_name: After Cologne, we can't let the bigots steal feminism

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Kaila Prins is a wellness coach specializing in disordered eating, dieting, exercise dependency, and distorted body image. Through her blog and podcasts, she brings together the experts in fitness, nutrition, health at every size, body acceptance, feminism, mindset and mental health, and more to unpack their bags and discuss their journeys to self-love. Kaila's talks focus on media literacy (shedding light on the marketing and manipulation of body image), the dangers and costs of dieting (and how to stop the yo-yo diet cycle), and the importance of self awareness and "discovery" in eating disorder prevention and recovery.

Her presentations include:

- Media Literacy and Body Image
- How to Stop Losing the Last 10 Pounds and Start Living Your Life Instead
- Advertising the Body: How to Survive in Culture Where the Body is Currency


[Image: A close up of featured speaker Kaila Prins looking up at the camera from an angle.]
link_name: Kaila Prins

It's Meet the Team Monday! 

Mahealani Joy is a writer, storyteller, and activist currently based out of Minnesota. They are a kanaka maoli (Native Hawaiian) non-binary queer with an intense passion for all things geeky. Mahealani currently works with a tribal sexual assault coalition to find culturally specific ways to support survivors and address sexual violence in Indigenous communities. When she isn't busy writing and trying to dismantle oppressive systems, she can usually be found reading, pondering what a world without violence would look like, and dreaming of the day she's able to get a dog. Read their EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1My3vSJ.

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event! 

Patricia Valoy is a Latina feminist activist and blogger, and a Civil Engineer who promotes STEM education for women. She combines her experiences as a Latina, a feminist, and an engineer to advocate and inspire girls considering careers in the fields of STEM and speak on transnational feminism. Patricia's work mostly revolves around the Latino/a community, feminism, cultural identity, gender stereotypes, and workplace sexism.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Bias, Sexism, and Stereotypes in STEM
- STEM Outreach for Girls and Minority Groups
- Working in a Male-Dominated Fields
- Battling Sexism in STEM, Construction, and Other Non-Traditionally Female Employment
- Transnational Feminism and Cultural Identity
- Latina/o Feminism and Ethno-Racial Identity


[Image: A photo of featured speaker Patricia Valoy sitting on a red sofa chair on a stage speaking into a mic.]
link_name: Patricia Valoy

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sam Dylan Finch is an LGBTQA+ and mental health educator. As a transgender and bipolar activist, Sam draws from his lived experience to defy the stigmas that surround his identity, as well as teaching others about the challenges that are faced by his communities. With a passion for stigma-busting and impacting change through personal narratives and storytelling, Sam is quickly becoming a powerful and accessible voice for queer, feminist, and mental health issue.

His presentations include:

- What is Queer Feminism?
- Queering Gender: Living Life Outside of the Binary
- In Trans*it: Transitioning as Non-Binary
- Stigma 101: Dismantling Shame and Healing Our Communities
- Neurodiversity and Self-Love
- Bipolar and Me


[Image: A black and white close-up of featured speaker Sam Dylan Finch, who is tilting his head and looking at the camera with a neutral expression.]
link_name: Sam Dylan Finch

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Jennifer Loubriel is a mixed race Afro-Puerto Rican from the Bronx. She is also a queer mujerista and child abuse survivor. She earned her B.A. from Oberlin College in Religion and English, and identifies as an amateur Latinx ethicist and a speculative fiction enthusiast. She has previously worked as a community organizer and educator, where she taught and (un)learned with some deeply fabulous young women. She is a co-founder and moderator over at the Tumblr Women of Color, in Solidarity (http://buff.ly/1PbOlJm), a safe space for and by women of color. Jennifer is an aspiring radical librarian who thinks a lot about policing in community spaces. You can usually find her writing about apocalypse and diaspora, rewatching her favorite TV shows, or taking selfies with her family's cat. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1mbbpMH.

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Taté Walker is a Lakota feminist activist, blogger, filmmaker, photographer, and social services professional who promotes cultural competency and inclusion for professionals in the workplace. Her experience includes more than 10 years as a newspaper reporter and freelance journalist, juvenile justice worker, teacher, and civil rights and family advocate. This, combined with her personal, professional and academic research in the areas of Native American identity and stereotypes, poverty, health, and sexuality, make Taté a dynamic and powerful speaker.

Her presentations include:

- Gender & Sexuality in Native American Cultures
- The Role of Women in Native American Societies from 1492 to Today
- Surviving Love: Promoting Awareness & Prevention of Violence Against Indigenous Women
- 566: An Introduction to Native American Cultural Competency
- Not Your Tonto: Native American Representations in Media
- The Harm of Indian Mascots on Native American Youth
- Not Your Cliché: A Look at the Stereotypes Plaguing Tribal Communities
- Columbus, the Discovery Myth, and the Importance of Teaching Indigenous Histories
- Moving Past the Thanksgiving Fairytale
- Topics specific to the Oceti Sakowin (Seven Council Fires, often mistakenly referred to as "Sioux")


[Image: A headshot of featured speaker Taté Walker, who is smiling as she faces the camera directly.]
link_name: Taté Walker

Hari Ziyad is a Brooklyn-based storyteller. He is the Editor in Chief of RaceBaitR (http://buff.ly/1OUmKft), a space dedicated to imagining and working toward a world outside of the white supremacist cisheteropatriarchal capitalistic gaze, and his work has been featured on Gawker, Out, Ebony, Mic, Colorlines, Black Girl Dangerous, Young Colored and Angry, The Feminist Wire, and The Each Other Project. He is also an assistant editor for Vinyl Poetry. Sometimes, he goes by "they." You can find him (mostly) ignoring racists on Twitter (http://buff.ly/1NJdHx7) and Facebook (http://buff.ly/21SFy3Y). Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Melissa A. Fabello is the Managing Editor of Everyday Feminism. She is also a domestic violence prevention and sexuality educator with a specialty in body image as well as a fierce feminist activist. With a passion for advocacy and a drive for liberation, Melissa's work revolves mostly around teenagers, body image, female sexuality, and media literacy.

Her presentations include:

- Media Literacy 101: How Pop Culture Seduces You into Gender Roles
- Bleeding Love: Pop Music, Advertising, and the Normalization of Dating Violence
- Reclaiming Our Bodies, Our Sexuality, Our Lives: Exploring Female Sexuality Through Five BS Body Myths
- I Know It Hurts, But Starving Works: How Pro-Eating Disorder Content on Social Media Harms Our Body Image and How to Fight Back
- Social Justice Activist Self-Care (or, Why My YouTube Comments Are Disabled): Why You Need It and How to Start


[Image: A close-up of featured speaker Melissa Fabello looking away from the camera.]

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Katherine Garcia is a recent college graduate with a B.A in Radio, TV, and Film who cannot wait to get back to the classroom. She is currently taking some time off before returning to school in pursuit of a Masters in Gender and Women's Studies. Although her interests are many, she has decided to focus her graduate research on the intersections of activist participation within the Latina feminist movement and how the Latina feminist movement has impacted and been impacted by the mainstream movement. Katherine identifies as a bisexual Puerto Rican woman of the non-spicy kind who has a huge crush on Frida Kahlo. She is passionate about LGBTQIA+ rights, domestic violence advocacy, Latinx issues, sexual abuse advocacy, and mental health awareness. She is also passionate about 80s hair metal, used bookstores, astrology, and chocolate. You can follow her on Twitter @TheLazyVegan1. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1TAtC1m.

[Image: A black and white headshot of featured team member Katherine Garcia smiling and facing the camera directly.]

Sexual assault against Native people are at a crisis level with the majority of perpetrators being non-Native. Yet Native Nations are not allowed to press criminal charges against non-Native people. And this Monday, Dec. 7th, they could lose their only tool ~ civil jurisdiction ~ unless we speak out.


[Image: A person holding an orange sign in front of a store with a logo reading "DOLLAR GENERAL" in black block letters. The sign says: "@Dollar General--Says not liable for employed #ChildMolester. #Colonizer #NativeJustice #RapeCulture".]

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sandra Kim is the Founding CEO & Co-Publisher of Everyday Feminism. Since its launch two years ago, Sandra has led Everyday Feminism to become one of the largest independent feminist media sites in the world, with 4.5 million visitors per month from over 150 countries. Sandra's commitment to intersectionality and belief in the interdependence of personal and social transformation have shaped Everyday Feminism's unique approach to feminism.

Her presentations include:

- Building Inclusive Leadership for Anti-Oppression Work Environments
- Bringing Intersectionality and Inclusiveness Into Our Daily Feminist Work
- Building an Intersectional and Inclusive Movement to End Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault
- Making Self-Care for Sustainable Activism the Norm
- Building a Massive Online Base for Social Change


[Image: A headshot of featured speaker Sandra Kim, who is sitting on a couch, crossing her arms, and smiling slightly as she looks at the camera.]
link_name: Sandra Kim

It's Meet the Team Monday!

Cara Liebowitz is a disabled activist and writer currently finishing a Master's Degree in Disability Studies from the CUNY School of Professional Studies in Manhattan, NY. In addition to working for Everyday Feminism, Cara serves as the co-chair for the Neurodiversity Caucus of the Society for Disability Studies and works with the Raise Advisory Partnership (RAP), creating materials to distribute to Parent Training Information Centers. Cara's writing has been published in Empowering Leadership: A Systems Change Guide for Autistic College Students and Those with Other Disabilities, Criptiques, and will be published in the upcoming Spoon Knife anthology from Autonomous Press. She travels around the country presenting on a variety of disability topics. Cara also blogs at her website, http://buff.ly/1Q2NUk0. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1jnX1yQ.

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Adrian is a genderqueer writer, activist, consultant, and social justice educator as well as a state-certified mediator and trained facilitator. Adrian has founded/directed six youth programs focusing on topics ranging from food justice/farming/cooking to community organizing to youth ministry. They also consult with organizations on how to best improve diversity practices for staff and clients. They specialize in working with non-profits and schools/youth organizations on building best practices for trans, non-binary, and/0r gender non-conforming safety and inclusion.

Their presentations include:

- Non-Binary Identities 101
- How to Make Your Organization More Trans Inclusive
- Creating Trans-Affirming Youth Spaces
- Feminism and Trans Identities
- Youth Organizing and Adultism

status_message:
(Content Warnings: Racism, gun violence)

If you still know of people who claim that the overall attitude of the police toward Black people and their shooting of unarmed Black people is not rooted in racism, please share this with them.

Last night, a group of white men - armed, masked, and wearing bulletproof vests - went to the crowd of peaceful unarmed Black protestors at the MN police station. This group had been coming on other nights so presumably the police knew their feelings (if it wasn't already clearly evident from their guns and gear) and still the police chose to not take any steps to protect the Black protestors. The white men then proceed to shoot into the crowd, wounding at least 5 Black people.

What do the police choose to do, especially given the fact that this happened only one block away from the police station that was filled with police officers? Let the white shooters leave and then fire a chemical irritant into the crowd of Black protestors (who had just been shot at). This isn't surprising unfortunately since the police have also been the other group of white people pointing guns at them during their non-violent protest.  

If the stark contrast between how the very same police chose to respond to this group of armed white men compared to the group of unarmed Black people who were being threatened with guns and being shot at doesn't scream of white supremacy to you, then wake the fuck up and ask yourself why you're trying so damn hard to protect and defend white people who shoot Black people!!
link_name: White supremacists shoot 5 Black Lives Matter activists protesting Jamar Clark's killing in...

status_message:
Dear US-based readers, 

If you're as horrified by Congress' scapegoating of Syrian refugees fleeing a violent and dangerous reality that the US has helped to create, please take a few seconds to read and sign this petition created by UltraViolet asking the Senate not to abandon the refugees. 

Sign here: http://act.weareultraviolet.org/sign/syrian_refugees/?source=uv_website

As Ultraviolet writes, 

"Last Thursday, the House of Representatives--including 47 Democrats--approved an extreme measure to effectively shut down the refugee program for Syrians fleeing ISIS.

Three-fourths of Syrian refugees are women and children--and none of the identified terrorist attackers in Paris were Syrian refugees. This reeks of the reckless fear-mongering that led us into the war in Iraq.

Twelve-year-old girls are being systematically raped by ISIS--it's part of their strategy to terrorize the Syrian population. We won't defeat extremism in Syria by turning our backs on families and survivors of rape and violence who are trying to flee the very terrorists we fear. We can still stop this horrible bill in the Senate, but we need to stand together strongly. Will you sign the petition?"

Sign here: http://act.weareultraviolet.org/sign/syrian_refugees/?source=uv_website


[Image: A photo of a young Syrian child walking outside holding a basket with a group of tents shown behind them.]
link_name: UltraViolet | We can't turn our backs on Syrian refugees

Nikita Redkar is a writer and comedienne based in Austin, Texas. She has bylines at xoJane, Hello Giggles, Fusion, and has punchlines at Reductress, Above Average, and Cafe. Her writing has also been mentioned in The Huffington Post and Buzzfeed. Nikita also has a column at Brown Girl Magazine dedicated to promoting sex positivity for South Asian women. She is a feminist, dog person, and astronomy nerd who graduated from Texas A&M University in 2015. Find out more at her website (http://buff.ly/1N18z7f) and follow her on Twitter @TheRedkarReport (http://buff.ly/1N18zUJ). Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1NHKWwB.

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Akilah Richards is a Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE) who specializes in women's emotional wellness.  Her work in centered on Radical Self-Expression, a practice she created to address societal oppression of the voices and needs of women and girls, and to explore the consequences and potential remedies therein. Akilah has created and delivered in-person and online workshops at college campuses, private summits, and public conferences about designing our ideal lives through the defining and exploration of self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle.

Her presentations include:

- Strategy & Soulwork for Radical Self-Expression
- Nurturing the Aha's: What to Do with Your Biggest Breakthroughs
- Life Design through Free-Range Learning: Exploring the Unschooling mindset
- Live Your Grain: Insights on Radical Lifestyle Management
- Life Chanting 101: How Incantations Support Spiritual Exploration

status_message:
Our hearts are heavy for everyone affected by the terrible attacks in Paris. Unfortunately, the people in France are experiencing now what is too often the daily reality in many countries. Places where people cannot walk around in their own communities without fear of similar random attacks, such as in Syria, Lebanon, Iraq, Afghanistan, Palestine, the Dominican Republic, and beyond – including communities facing terror and interpersonal violence without support or media recognition. This is an incomplete list of examples and we extend wishes for peace and healing to people facing violence everywhere.

As the American government and people rightly offer their support to France, let us not forget how the American government and its foreign policy are a driving factor in the daily terror experienced in other countries. When we see news reports of this violence, will you extend the same compassion and understanding you have for the innocent people hurt and killed in France to the innocent people hurt and killed in the Middle East?

And as we show our support for the French people suffering the direct impact of these attacks, let's not forget the millions of refugees fleeing harrowing violence in their own home countries. When they show up in your country, will you demand they be treated with dignity and be provided the safety and support they need?

We also know, unfortunately, that after attacks such as this, some people wrongly join the cycle of violence with xenophobia and Islamophobia. When those around you blame refugees and Muslim people and call for violence against them in retaliation, how will you help humanize the innocent people being falsely characterized as "the enemy"? 

And when Black Americans protest against police violence and are killed and beaten with impunity in their homes, playgrounds, schools, and neighborhoods, will you speak out too? 

We ask that you do, because nobody should have to live in fear. 

Nobody.

And we shouldn't have forces like racism and neo-colonialism direct our empathy for us – to a Western world that feels familiar, but not to Beirut, not to Baghdad. 

Let us not join in the cycle of violence – let's instead hold each other in peace and empathy during this time. 
Let us use this moment of compassion to show solidarity with everyone else who knows this fear and sadness.
Let us not feel helpless in the face of such random acts of violence. Let's instead begin to look out for each other – in our own homes and communities, across our country and the world.

Do society's gender norms influence your idea of consent? Read this author's break-down and you'll understand why our perspectives need to change – and how we can start to change them.


[Image: A blue post-it note with a question mark on it pinned on a bulletin board, with multicolored post-its circling it, each reading "yes," "no," "don't care," "don't know," and "maybe."]
link_name: The Problem With How We've Defined Consent

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Ginny Brown is a writer, sexuality educator, and birth worker. Her first decade of adulthood was spent making the journey from "homeschooled conservative Christian" to "queer polyamourous humanist." Now she's rocking it with an M.Ed in Human Sexuality from Widener University, and happily living in Philadelphia with her family of four adult humans and two cats. She is passionate about helping people know and love themselves better, and all of her work in sex education is secretly (or not-so-secretly) aimed at that goal. She's also working toward doula certification and super-excited to help people of all genders navigate pregnancy, birth, and new parenthood. She lazily co-writes a blog with her brother at The Brunette's Blog (http://buff.ly/1NV5zIl), and has been known to dabble in fiction writing as well. You can follow her on Twitter @lirelyn. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1Q9B9FG!

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Creigh Farinas is a neurodiversity activist and blogger, and an advocate for autism acceptance. Despite studying autism as part of her coursework, her extensive knowledge about autistic and disabled people's perspectives comes from her personal background as a sibling of an Autistic woman and former caregiver for children on the autism spectrum. She uses her experiences and observations to inform her as she attempts to amplify the voices of autistic people. Creigh's background mostly revolves around disability rights, neurodiversity, and autism acceptance.

Her presentations include:

- Autistic People Can Lead Happy Lives: Helping Them Get There
- Why Would Anyone Want to Accept Autism? An Explanation of the Autism Acceptance Movement 
- Presuming Competence: What That Means for You
- The Social Model of Disability: How Someone Can Be Simultaneously Very and Not at All Disabled
- How to Be an Ally to Neurodiverse People
- Teaching Kids about Disabilities
- What is Autism?

[Image: A headshot of featured speaker Creigh Farinas smiling against a brown background and turning toward the camera at an angle.]

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Emma Rust is a bisexual, mixed race, Asian American printmaker and cartoonist. Originally from Los Angeles, Emma is currently attending Whitman College in Washington State, in the pursuit of an Art and Psych degree. She interns at a sexual violence prevention organization with a focus on creating comics and prints that talk about sexual violence and consent in ways that are constantly engaging and educating the student body. In addition, she is working on a developmental psychology intervention focused on minimizing the achievement gap in at-risk infants. Other than that, she mostly spends time drinking tea while browsing Tumblr or watching anime on Netflix that she will mostly likely silently critique for being misogynistic or not racially inclusive. For more of her art, check out her Tumblr (http://buff.ly/1VUAy9k). Check out her EF work here: http://buff.ly/1OFI9rS.

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism Speaker to your event!

Kaila Prins is a wellness coach specializing in disordered eating, dieting, exercise dependency, and distorted body image. Through her blog and podcasts, she brings together the experts in fitness, nutrition, health at every size, body acceptance, feminism, mindset and mental health, and more to unpack their bags and discuss their journeys to self-love. Kaila's talks focus on media literacy (shedding light on the marketing and manipulation of body image), the dangers and costs of dieting (and how to stop the yo-yo diet cycle), and the importance of self awareness and "discovery" in eating disorder prevention and recovery.

Her presentations include:

- Media Literacy and Body Image
- How to Stop Losing the Last 10 Pounds and Start Living Your Life Instead
- Advertising the Body: How to Survive in Culture Where the Body is Currency


[Image: A close-up of featured speaker Kaila Prins. She is standing outside in front of a green bush and looking at the camera with a slight smile.]

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Patricia Valoy is a Latina feminist activist and blogger, and a Civil Engineer who promotes STEM education for women. She combines her experiences as a Latina, a feminist, and an engineer to advocate and inspire girls considering careers in the fields of STEM and speak on transnational feminism. Patricia's work mostly revolves around the Latino/a community, feminism, cultural identity, gender stereotypes, and workplace sexism.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Bias, Sexism, and Stereotypes in STEM
- STEM Outreach for Girls and Minority Groups
- Working in a Male-Dominated Fields
- Battling Sexism in STEM, Construction, and Other Non-Traditionally Female Employment
- Transnational Feminism and Cultural Identity
- Latina/o Feminism and Ethno-Racial Identity


[Image: A photo of featured speaker Patricia Valoy sitting on a red sofa chair on a stage, speaking into a microphone in her hand and holding her other hand out palm up.]

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Tina Vasquez is a freelance writer and editor with nearly 10 years of experience. Her work in independent media primarily focuses on feminism and racial justice. She is a 2014 VONA/Voices of Our Nations Arts Foundation alumna and the winner of the Media Consortium's 2015 Impact Award for her Bitch Media story "It's Time to End the Long History of Feminism Failing Transgender Women." She is the former associate editor at Black Girl Dangerous and a contributor to Bitch Magazine, Autostraddle, and Jezebel. Vasquez is also the writer of Liberty For All, a comic strip about a queer, undocumented Latina named Liberty Martinez. The graphic novel Liberty For All: The First Season will be published in the fall of 2015. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1KDVMlr.

[Image: A close up of featured team member Tina Vasquez's face. She has long curly black hair and is looking at the camera with a serious facial expression.]

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sam Dylan Finch is an LGBTQA+ and mental health educator. As a transgender and bipolar activist, Sam draws from his lived experience to defy the stigmas that surround his identity, as well as teaching others about the challenges that are faced by his communities. With a passion for stigma-busting and impacting change through personal narratives and storytelling, Sam is quickly becoming a powerful and accessible voice for queer, feminist, and mental health issue.

His presentations include:

- What is Queer Feminism?
- Queering Gender: Living Life Outside of the Binary
- In Trans*it: Transitioning as Non-Binary
- Stigma 101: Dismantling Shame and Healing Our Communities
- Neurodiversity and Self-Love
- Bipolar and Me


[Image: A black and white headshot of featured speaker Sam Dylan Finch, who has short straight hair, is wearing a patterned sweater, and is tilting his head to the side.]
link_name: Sam Dylan Finch

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Taté Walker is a Lakota feminist activist, blogger, filmmaker, photographer, and social services professional who promotes cultural competency and inclusion for professionals in the workplace. Her experience includes more than 10 years as a newspaper reporter and freelance journalist, juvenile justice worker, teacher, and civil rights and family advocate. This, combined with her personal, professional and academic research in the areas of Native American identity and stereotypes, poverty, health, and sexuality, make Taté a dynamic and powerful speaker.

Her presentations include:

- Gender & Sexuality in Native American Cultures
- The Role of Women in Native American Societies from 1492 to Today
- Surviving Love: Promoting Awareness & Prevention of Violence Against Indigenous Women
- 566: An Introduction to Native American Cultural Competency
- Not Your Tonto: Native American Representations in Media
- The Harm of Indian Mascots on Native American Youth
- Not Your Cliché: A Look at the Stereotypes Plaguing Tribal Communities
- Columbus, the Discovery Myth, and the Importance of Teaching Indigenous Histories
- Moving Past the Thanksgiving Fairytale
- Topics specific to the Oceti Sakowin (Seven Council Fires, often mistakenly referred to as "Sioux")


[Image: A close up of featured speaker Taté Walker, how has long straight brown hair, is wearing a patterned black and white sweater, and is smiling while facing the camera.]
link_name: Taté Walker

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Kai Cheng Thom is a writer, performance artist, social worker, and glitter enthusiast based in Montreal, Canada. In addition to Everyday Feminism, her articles have been published in xoJane, Youngist, and Montreal Review of Books. Her poetry has appeared in Matrix Magazine, Ditch, Yellow Noise Magazine, and the anthology Where the Nights are Twice as Long: Love Letters of Canadian Poets. A little Chinese trans girl with a big, lipsticked mouth, she has rocked spoken word stages from Vancouver to Halifax. Kai also holds a Master's degree in social work and is training to become a psychotherapist. She is the co-founder of Monster Academy Montreal, a youth mental health education collective. In her spare time, Kai is learning to pick locks and make dresses. You can check out her website (http://buff.ly/1iAuNAZ), follow her poetry Tumblr (http://buff.ly/1iAuMNy), or follow her on Facebook (http://buff.ly/1iAuOVM)! Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1OE1KXo

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Melissa A. Fabello is the Managing Editor of Everyday Feminism. She is also a domestic violence prevention and sexuality educator with a specialty in body image as well as a fierce feminist activist. With a passion for advocacy and a drive for liberation, Melissa's work revolves mostly around teenagers, body image, female sexuality, and media literacy.

Her presentations include:

- Media Literacy 101: How Pop Culture Seduces You into Gender Roles
- Bleeding Love: Pop Music, Advertising, and the Normalization of Dating Violence
- Reclaiming Our Bodies, Our Sexuality, Our Lives: Exploring Female Sexuality Through Five BS Body Myths
- I Know It Hurts, But Starving Works: How Pro-Eating Disorder Content on Social Media Harms Our Body Image and How to Fight Back
- Social Justice Activist Self-Care (or, Why My YouTube Comments Are Disabled): Why You Need It and How to Start


[Image: A close of of featured speaker Melissa Fabello, who has long wavy brown hair, looking away from the camera.]
link_name: Melissa A. Fabello

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sandra Kim is the Founding CEO & Co-Publisher of Everyday Feminism. Since its launch two years ago, Sandra has led Everyday Feminism to become one of the largest independent feminist media sites in the world, with 4.5 million visitors per month from over 150 countries. Sandra's commitment to intersectionality and belief in the interdependence of personal and social transformation have shaped Everyday Feminism's unique approach to feminism. Her presentations include:

- Bringing Intersectionality and Inclusiveness Into Our Daily Feminist Work
- Building an Intersectional and Inclusive Movement to End Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault
- Building Inclusive Leadership
- How Marginalized People Can Create Leadership Spaces for Ourselves
- Making Self-Care for Sustainable Activism the Norm
- Starting a Sustainable Online Business for Social Change
- Building a Massive Online Base for Social Change


[Image: A headshot of featured speaker Sandra Kim, who has short straight black hair and is wearing a grey shirt, sitting on a bench, crossing her arms, and smiling.]
link_name: Sandra Kim

Jenika McCrayer is a Virginia native and has a BA in Women and Gender Studies from The College of William and Mary. She is currently pursuing an MA in the same field. This AmeriCorps alumna is passionate about community service and strives for a better understanding of how to mobilize marginalized populations through service and activism. Jenika also enjoys good books, bad horror films, naps, and the beach. Follow her on Twitter @JenikaMc (http://buff.ly/1O06iaf). Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1KtDojR.

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Adrian Ballou is a genderqueer writer, activist, consultant, and social justice educator as well as a state-certified mediator and trained facilitator. Adrian has founded/directed six youth programs focusing on topics ranging from food justice/farming/cooking to community organizing to youth ministry. They also consult with organizations on how to best improve diversity practices for staff and clients. They specialize in working with non-profits and schools/youth organizations on building best practices for trans, non-binary, and/or gender non-conforming safety and inclusion.

- Non-Binary Identities 101
- How to Make Your Organization More Trans Inclusive
- Creating Trans-Affirming Youth Spaces
- Feminism and Trans Identities
- Youth Organizing and Adultism

To book Adrian, check out: 
http://everydayfeminism.com/speakers-bureau/adrian-ballou/

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Sam Dylan Finch is a transgender writer, activist, and educator, based in the San Francisco Bay Area. A passionate feminist and social justice advocate, Sam explores topics such as non-binary identity, mental health and illness, body image, radical self-love, and queer feminism. Sam draws from his lived experience on the queer and bipolar spectrum with the hopes of educating others about his communities and challenging the stigmas that surround his identity. In addition to being a Feature Writer at Everyday Feminism, Sam is the founder of Let's Queer Things Up! (http://buff.ly/1hybEzx) and his work can be found on platforms like the Huffington Post, Ravishly, The New York Times, and most notably, on his mom's refrigerator. Tweet him at @samdylanfinch so you can chat about all things Mary Lambert, cats, and pizza. Find him on Facebook (http://buff.ly/1MISiVl) or learn more about him at his personal website (http://buff.ly/1PE9cCS. Read his EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1PE9h9u.

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Akilah Richards is a Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE) who specializes in women's emotional wellness. Her work in centered on Radical Self-Expression, a practice she created to address societal oppression of the voices and needs of women and girls, and to explore the consequences and potential remedies therein. Akilah has created and delivered in-person and online workshops at college campuses, private summits, and public conferences about designing our ideal lives through the defining and exploration of self-expression, womanhood, modern feminism, location independence, and the unschooling lifestyle. Her presentations include:

- Strategy & Soulwork for Radical Self-Expression
- Nurturing the Aha's: What to Do with Your Biggest Breakthroughs
- Life Design through Free-Range Learning: Exploring the Unschooling mindset
- Live Your Grain: Insights on Radical Lifestyle Management
- Life Chanting 101: How Incantations Support Spiritual Exploration


[Image: A close up of featured speaker Akilah Richards, who has long brown dreadlocks, standing in front of a body of water looking directly towards the camera.]
link_name: Akilah S. Richards

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Ashley Truong is a queer diasporic Vietnamese womxn. She graduated this spring with a double degree in English and Asian American Studies. She doesn't know when exactly she became a feminist, just that she learned about it through social media and thought, "Wow, this explains so many things about my life." She believes that feminist activism — as well as any other kind of activism — must be done with compassion. As such, she strives to remember the people who are affected by all the oppressive events happening, and to make sure that their needs, not outrage, comes first. When she's not philosophizing about this at length, she's reading, taking long walks, or cooing over all the dogs who cross her path. Read her articles here http://buff.ly/1WuG5Xk.

Jamie Utt is a diversity and inclusion consultant and sexual violence prevention educator to combat prejudice, bigotry, and hate in all its forms. One of the most dynamic new voices for change and inclusion today, his interactive presentations have empowered thousands to take personal accountability for making this world a better place. His presentations include:

- Yes Please! Making Consent Fun and Sexy
- Party On! Building Sex Positive Party Culture
- Man Up: Building Positive Masculinity
- The Wall: Understanding Your Own Power, Oppression, and Privilege
- The Antidote: How Students Can Create a More Inclusive School

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

B. Cole is the Founder and Executive Director of Brown Boi Project, a community of masculine of center womyn, men, two-spirit people, transmen, and allies committed to transforming privileges of masculinity, gender, and race into tools for achieving racial and gender justice. As a young queer consultant of color with almost ten years consulting and facilitation experience, she is often uniquely positioned to bring together groups across divides. Her presentations include:

- Gender Justice
- The New Masculinity

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Michal "MJ" Jones is an awkward, Black, non-binary queer educator, activist, and musician writing to you from Oakland, CA. They're hella into building spaces for queer and trans* youth of color, practicing kindness, using education as a tool of liberation, and making the personal political. They earned their BA in Sociology from Sonoma State University, where they served as president of the Queer Straight Alliance and advocated for students of color. They went on to earn an MA in Student Development Administration from Seattle University and remain committed to improving access and retention to higher education. Listen to their music (http://buff.ly/1KFG500) or read more of their work (http://buff.ly/1Iymr6G). Follow them on Twitter @JustSayMJ and read their Everyday Feminism articles here: http://buff.ly/1MCa4cd.

[Image: A close-up of featured team member MJ Jones, who has short brown dreadlocks and black-rimmed glasses.]

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

An award-winning public high school teacher in Seattle, Jon Greenberg gained broader recognition for standing up for racial dialogue in the classroom—with widespread support from community—while a school district attempted to stifle it. With nearly 20 years of diverse teaching experiences under his belt, he has long dedicated his teaching career to social justice and civic engagement. His presentations include:

- Teaching a Unit on Race: Practical Lessons on a Taboo Topic
- The Race Curriculum Controversy: The Benefits and Costs of Social Justice Teaching
- Civic Engagement 101: Connecting Your Classroom to the Community

Happy 3rd Birthday Everyday Feminism!!! 

It's been an incredible last year and we want to give you so much love for being part of this amazing EF community. <3 <3

We want to make next year even better so would love to hear what you enjoy most about EF and what you'd like to see more of in the future.

As you know we take your input really seriously so we'll be reviewing all your ideas and feedback to help guide our editorial planning for next year.

Thank you so much again - and click to see a little infographic of some of the highlights and stats from the last year!

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Rachel Kuo is a scholar and educator based in New York City. She is starting the doctoral program in Media, Culture, and Communications at New York University. Her professional background is in designing curriculum and also communications strategy for social justice education initiatives. Currently, she works full-time at NYU's Center for Multicultural Education and Programs. Her writing and research interests include racial justice, media justice and digital media activism. She also loves learning about animals (especially dinosaurs and marine life), watching Chopped while ellipticalling, and eating any and all noodle varieties. You can follow her on Twitter @rachelkuo. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1HP6oj6.

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Creigh is a neurodiversity activist and blogger, and an advocate for autism acceptance. Despite studying autism as part of her coursework, her extensive knowledge about autistic and disabled people's perspectives comes from her personal background as a sibling of an Autistic woman and former caregiver for children on the autism spectrum.

She uses her experiences and observations to inform her as she attempts to amplify the voices of autistic people. Creigh's background mostly revolves around disability rights, neurodiversity, and autism acceptance.

- Autistic People Can Lead Happy Lives: Helping Them Get There
- Why Would Anyone Want to Accept Autism? An Explanation of the Autism Acceptance Movement Presuming Competence: What That Means for You
- The Social Model of Disability: How Someone Can Be Simultaneously Very and Not at All Disabled
- How to Be an Ally to Neurodiverse People
- Teaching Kids about Disabilities
- What is Autism?

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Kaila Prins is a health coach living in Silicon Valley who works with women who are ready to stop "recovering" from disordered eating and start "discovering" their true identities. A former anorexic and exercise addict herself, Kaila knows intimately the cycle of restrict-relapse-repeat – and while she believes that recovery from an eating disorder is a mixture of consciousness and chemicals, which requires nourishing your body and your soul – too many women get caught up in the food and forget to find themselves. Kaila writes on eating disorders, body image, and recovery at In My Skinny Genes (http://buff.ly/1CH0EsW), and she hosts a weekly podcast called Finding Our Hunger (http://buff.ly/1THeFeg), where she and her co-host interview the "experts" in fitness, nutrition, and body love to unpack their bags and unashamedly air what they find inside. She also counts characters and not calories on Twitter @MissSkinnyGenes. Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1THeJL8.

[Image: A close-up of featured team member Kaila Prins, who has ear-length brown hair and is looking at the camera at a 3/4 angle.]

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Patricia Valoy is a Latina feminist activist and blogger, and a Civil Engineer who promotes STEM education for women.

She combines her experiences as a Latina, a feminist, and an engineer to advocate and inspire girls considering careers in the fields of STEM and speak on transnational feminism. Patricia's work mostly revolves around the Latino/a community, feminism, cultural identity, gender stereotypes, and workplace sexism.

Her presentations include:

- Gender Bias, Sexism, and Stereotypes in STEM
- STEM Outreach for Girls and Minority Groups
- Working in a Male-Dominated Fields
- Battling Sexism in STEM, Construction, and Other Non-Traditionally Female Employment
- Transnational Feminism and Cultural Identity
- Latina/o Feminism and Ethno-Racial Identity


[Image: Featured speaker Patricia Valoy sitting in a red arm chair in front of a red curtain, speaking into a microphone in her hand and holding her left hand out.]
link_name: Patricia Valoy

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Annah Anti-Palindrome is a Bay Area based musician/sound-artist, writer, and queer/femme antagonist who hails from the working-class craters at the base of the Sierra Foothills. Annah holds a BA in Women and Gender Studies from San Francesco State University and an MFA in Creative Writing from Mills College. Her work explores the feminist intersections between art-activism, anti-racist allyship, class rage, literacy, femmephobia, mental health, sobriety culture, and more! For additional information on her work, see her website (http://buff.ly/1Hq5Qx1) or connect with her on Facebook (http://buff.ly/1UK9sUD). Read her EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1UK9xYn!

status_message:
Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sam Dylan Finch is an LGBTQA+ and mental health educator. As a transgender and bipolar activist, Sam draws from his lived experience to defy the stigmas that surround his identity, as well as teaching others about the challenges that are faced by his communities.

With a passion for stigma-busting and impacting change through personal narratives and storytelling, Sam is quickly becoming a powerful and accessible voice for queer, feminist, and mental health issue

His presentations include:

- What is Queer Feminism?
- Queering Gender: Living Life Outside of the Binary
- In Trans*it: Transitioning as Non-Binary
- Stigma 101: Dismantling Shame and Healing Our Communities
- Neurodiversity and Self-Love
- Bipolar and Me


[Image: A black and white closeup of featured speaker Sam Dylan Finch, who has short brown hair and black glasses and is tilting his head to his left.]
link_name: Sam Dylan Finch

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Creigh Farinas is a graduate student pursuing a Master's degree in Speech Language Pathology. She has a B.A. in Psychology and completed a post-baccalaureate in Communication Sciences and Disorders. Absolutely none of those things, however, gave her understanding of autistic people's perspectives, let alone disability rights. Instead, all her knowledge was gained learning from people on the autism spectrum and other disabilities themselves, particularly her sister, Caley, who is Autistic and has dysgraphia and anxiety disorders. Creigh is still learning more every day, and her sister Caley reads, edits, and approves everything that Creigh writes about disabilities. You can see more of Creigh and Caley's writing here (http://buff.ly/1CQSN6z) (or in Spanish here: http://buff.ly/1CQSOaH). They also explain autism for children on the spectrum and siblings here (http://buff.ly/1JCWYe9) and here (http://buff.ly/1CQSOaJ). Read her and Caley's EF articles here: http://buff.ly/1NDExVc 

[Image: A headshot of featured team member Creigh Farinas, who has ear-length straight brown hair and black glasses and is smiling widely straight at the camera.]
link_name: Timeline Photos

Bring an Everyday Feminism speaker to your event!

Sara Alcid is a queer feminist political organizer, writer, and speaker based in Washington, DC. Her activism and writing focus on rape culture, reproductive justice, economic justice, and queer rights.

With an academic background in gender and sexuality studies, she bridges feminist theory and intersectional social justice organizing to make feminism accessible and empowering for all.

Her presentations include:

- Reality vs. Law & Order: SVU
- The Politics of Sex and Reproductive Justice
- Feminist Theory for the Everyday Feminist
- Queer Alphabet Soup
- The Power of Rural and Red State Feminism

status_message:
It's Meet the Team Monday!

Justin Dennis is a polyamorous, atheist, gender non-binary transwoman with a passion for fiction writing, feminism, and technology. She got her BA from Whittier College in 2015 doing a self-designed major called Writing Worlds, a mixture of creative writing and anthropology focused on realistic fictional world building. She sees writing novels and stories as a creative way to discuss important issues. She's the author of the Through the Portal trilogy (http://bit.ly/1BRl9CF) as well as the Android Section Editor for MakeUseOf.com. She was a journalist at the student-run Quaker Campus newspaper for four years, served as both Editor-in-Chief and Managing Editor at different times, and worked to change Whittier College's policies concerning sexual assault. Though originally from the Seattle area, she studied abroad in Sweden for five months and hopes to continue traveling around the world. In her daily life, she feels particularly passionate about ending rape culture, victim-blaming, and slut-shaming, as well as educating people on the nuances of gender, sexuality, and intersectional feminism. She's also super tall at 6'4" and loves casually playing sports and video games. Find her on YouTube (http://buff.ly/1QUdElk), Twitter @JustinDennis4, or her website http://buff.ly/1Gy0Uqg. Check out her EF work here: http://buff.ly/1QUdL03. 
 
[Image: A headshot of featured team member Justin Dennis, who has shoulder-length brown hair and is smiling widely.]

status_message:
10 Examples of Straight Privilege

The US Supreme Court has just ruled in favor of marriage equality. That's great! But we still live in a society where straight people have rights, power, and freedom that influence their lives in so many ways. Here are some examples of how straight privilege comes into play. 


[Image: A close up of two arms reaching towards each other. The arm on the right side is putting a diamond ring on the ring finger of the arm on the left.]
